articles.title: My petty gripe: my toddler’s a night owl. Where are all the 5pm kids’ activities?
articles.trailText: Yes, Ikea is not the ideal place for a shrieking, giggling, curious toddler who is awake hours after other children have dozed off. But nowhere is
articles.summary: Facing a two-year-old Formula One–speed night owl who won’t sleep until other kids have dozed, the author finds all 5 pm venues closed by 4 pm. Morning-only classes (swimming, gymnastics, football) demand pre-booking; library rhyme-time and museums wrap by late afternoon. Left with high-risk supermarkets or pubs, the family camps in IKEA’s faux kitchen until 8 pm, chasing their toddler as he traces a “driver’s line” through cubbyholes with F1 precision. IKEA fish & chips sustain them. Parents crave a late-opening soft-play café with safe zones, better food and even a soundproof scream room.

articles.title: The Piper Alpha oil rig exploded and collapsed – and I made a desperate 175ft jump into the sea
articles.trailText: In July 1988, the North Sea oil platform ignited. As it melted around him, Joe Meanen knew there was only one possible, but highly perilous, way out for him
articles.summary: On 6 July 1988, North Sea platform Piper Alpha suffered catastrophic explosions after a faulty gas pump was activated during maintenance, killing 167 of 228 crew. Scaffolder Joe Meanen, facing thick black smoke and collapsing decks, chose a desperate 175ft jump into the sea. Burned and scarred, he followed flames to surface lifeboat wreckage and was rescued. The subsequent public inquiry blamed operator OPCAL for safety failings, prompting 106 North Sea safety reforms. Meanen, who never returned offshore, now speaks on safety, maintains a survivors’ network and credits physical scars for aiding his mental recovery, honouring those who perished.

articles.title: Houseplant clinic: what’s wrong with the leaves on my rubber plant?
articles.trailText: Dropped leaves and speckled dots indicate a thrips infestation. Luckily, there is plenty you can do about it
articles.summary: Speckled black dots on rubber plant leaves are thrips droppings indicating an infestation by tiny sap-sucking insects. They cause silvery streaks, yellowing, curling and leaf drop, often mistaken for nutrient or sun damage. To treat, gently wipe foliage, then spray with pesticide weekly to break the life cycle; for prized specimens introduce biological controls like predatory mites (Amblyseius cucumeris). Prevent recurrence by boosting humidity, quarantining outdoor plants for 14 days before bringing them indoors, inspecting new growth—especially undersides—and maintaining vigilance to detect and address thrips early.

articles.title: ‘Drinking was big!’ Pub landlords – one gen Z, one 66 – discuss how they stay open in an age of sobriety
articles.trailText: Last year, more than 400 pubs closed in England and Wales, as rising costs kept customers at home and drinking rates among young people declined. Can any remain afloat? Two landlords from different generations discuss the problems and possibilities
articles.summary: Coby Morton, 28, of the Dolphin Inn in Shrewsbury, and 66-year-old Jason Osborne, owner of four pubs across England, reflect on a sector hit by over 600 closures in 2024–25 amid soaring costs and a generational drinking decline. With per-capita consumption down from a 2004 peak of 9.5 L and 43% of 18–34s abstaining, they’ve pivoted to music nights, board-game and knitting events, running clubs, low-ABV beers and strategic pricing while battling energy, staffing and kitchen expenses. Loyal regulars and community spirit endure, but future viability remains uncertain.

articles.title: Why young women are having facelifts: ‘I couldn’t even open my eyes. That’s how swollen I was’
articles.trailText: A new kind of customer is being driven towards this invasive surgery by ‘filler fatigue’, the use of weight-loss drugs and the development of new surgical techniques. Many are much younger than ever before
articles.summary: A wave of ‘filler fatigue,’ weight-loss drugs and affordable medical tourism, plus influencer-endorsed deep-plane techniques, has driven 20- and 30-somethings to elective facelifts—once the preserve of 40-plus patients. Cases include Florida realtor Amanda Preisinger, 30, whose overfilled features prompted a mid-facelift in Turkey that left her eyes so swollen she could barely open them, and London’s 28-year-olds seeking aesthetic “beautification.” BAAPS and US surgeons note an 8% UK lift increase and 32% of US patients now aged 35–55, but warn against operating on younger patients solely for lifestyle reasons.

articles.title: Halloween used to feel wrong in Australia, but now I gleefully await the spooky day
articles.trailText: After decades of scoffing at after-school trick-or-treaters, I now wear a witch’s hat and hit the streets with my junior hobgoblins
articles.summary: Halloween, once dismissed as an American fad in sunny Australia, is now a community highlight. After a 1990s first trick-or-treat confusion and years of parental scepticism—including mouldy pumpkin lessons—an impromptu pandemic-era street party converted the author. Today, mid-October Facebook maps and eco-decor tips pave the way for lawns dotted with inflatables, skeletons in gumtrees and sanitiser-topped letterboxes. On 31 October, children in costumes roam for lollies delivered via fishing-rod contraptions, while adults reconnect with neighbours. These few magical hours of supervised street-wide trick-or-treating cement Halloween’s place in Aussie neighbourhood life.

articles.title: You be the judge: take part in our live event
articles.trailText: On Wednesday 26 November, we’re hosting An evening of Guardian culture with Tim Dowling, Stuart Heritage and Meera Sodha , we need your help to bring one real domestic gripe onto the stage
articles.summary: The Guardian’s You be the judge feature is going live on Wednesday 26 November 2025 at Kings Place, London, as part of “An evening of Guardian culture” with Tim Dowling, Stuart Heritage and Meera Sodha. Readers are invited to submit one unresolved, comic domestic dispute—think fridge wars or laundry spats—for live arbitration by our panel and audience. Both parties must consent; deadline 10 November 2025. Selected participants receive £100 Trullo gift cards and Tim Siadatan’s Padella cookbook. UK residents only. Data will be used solely for the event; see Guardian terms and privacy policy.

articles.title: The one change that worked: I adopted a one-in, one-out wardrobe policy and rediscovered my love of clothes
articles.trailText: Online shopping made buying so easy that every time I picked up my phone I was in danger of adding to my outfits – and shrinking my bank account
articles.summary: A lifelong sustainable fashion fan turned Vinted addict, the author found herself drowning in secondhand buys and debt despite eco-good intentions. Inspired by a traveller’s one-in, one-out rule, she now sells an item on Vinted (or donates it after a month unsold) before adding a new piece, using only her Vinted credit. This habit curbs impulse scrolling, boosts wardrobe creativity, and brings cherished charity-shop treasures back into rotation. The policy transformed her Gen Z shopping—fostering mindful purchasing, outfit repetition without guilt, and confidence to wear what truly reflects her style.

articles.title: From ‘mood hoovers’ to ‘energy vampires’ - here’s why negative friends are good for you | Emma Beddington
articles.trailText: Jamie Oliver says he’s only hanging out with ‘lovely people’ in his 50s. But sometimes we all need an Eeyore around
articles.summary: Guardian columnist Emma Beddington uses her own midlife existential reflections—fading relevance, Dalí-clock neck and a binge on A Place in the Sun—to challenge Jamie Oliver’s advice to ‘edit away’ negative people or ‘mood hoovers.’ Embracing the ‘energy vampire’ label, she argues that gloomy friends, more like Eeyore than a wet blanket, provide candid feedback and pragmatic warnings—such as preventing someone from writing a children’s book about an Australian First Nations character without community consultation—a service ‘lovely people’ won’t offer.

articles.title: Is it true that … hangovers get worse as we age?
articles.trailText: We ask an expert whether the morning after really does become more severe as we get older
articles.summary: Research shows hangovers worsen with age as the liver produces fewer alcohol-metabolising enzymes, leaving acetaldehyde lingering longer, while body water declines by around 5% after 55, concentrating alcohol in the bloodstream and intensifying dehydration, and slower kidney function delays waste elimination. Professor Adam Taylor advises there’s no cure; prevention relies on moderation—alternating drinks with water and staying within weekly guidelines. Once symptoms begin, only time, rehydration and paracetamol ease the headache and grogginess. Awareness of these age-related physiological shifts explains why older adults often suffer harsher aftereffects.

articles.title: A new start after 60: I got divorced and spent a year trying 70 new things – from pole-dancing to spring rolls
articles.trailText: After a lifetime of thinking about others, Alese Johnston decided to put herself first. Adventurous and irresponsible, she’s happier than she has ever been
articles.summary: At 70, Arkansas-based entrepreneur Alese Johnston, newly divorced after 30 years of marriage, set out to do 70 novel activities in one year—documented on Fabulous70.com—to rediscover herself. Her list ranged from sampling spring rolls and pole-dancing and flying lessons to attending an erotic-blueprint workshop that “pushed boundaries.” Therapy and journaling helped her confront lifelong people-pleasing and fear of “irresponsibility” instilled by her strict upbringing. A former mainframe coder turned consultant, she now designs a loneliness-fighting longevity project. Completing her 70th adventure, Johnston says embracing curiosity and self-permission has led her to the happiest season of her life.

articles.title: Caroline Flack’s mum, Christine, on seeking answers and setting the record straight
articles.trailText: It’s five years since the TV presenter killed herself after being charged with assaulting her partner. Her mother Christine wants the world to know what the police, crown prosecution service and media got wrong
articles.summary: In her new Disney+ documentary Caroline Flack: Search for the Truth, Christine Flack investigates the chaotic final months before her daughter Caroline’s 2020 suicide, challenging police, CPS and tabloid narratives. She examines the December 2019 assault charge—overturned CPS warning, bail conditions and sensational headlines—that cost Caroline her job, home and mental wellbeing. Featuring former prosecutor Nazir Afzal’s admission that the case should have been cautioned, the film scrutinizes potential celebrity bias in prosecution and media vilification. Christine seeks clarity on systemic failures and aims to set the record straight on her daughter’s treatment and legacy.

articles.title: How much washing do our clothes really need?
articles.trailText: The long-running series in which readers answer other readers’ questions on subjects ranging from trivial flights of fancy to profound scientific and philosophical concepts
articles.summary: In this installment of a long-running Guardian series, readers are asked to weigh in on how often everyday garments truly need laundering and whether modern washing-machine cycles—regular, quick or lengthy two-hour programs—are necessary. The query invites practical tips on balancing cleanliness, fabric care and resource use, highlighting concerns over energy, water and time costs. Submissions, including fresh questions, are solicited via email for possible inclusion in next Sunday’s feature, reflecting the community-driven exploration of mundane yet universally relevant chores.

articles.title: The kindness of strangers: when I found out my cancer had spread, the woman in the next bed reached out
articles.trailText: The doctors told me I would need a second mastectomy and extensive chemotherapy. I felt as if I’d been hit by a truck
articles.summary: After discovering her breast cancer had spread to lymph nodes and the other breast post-mastectomy, the author learned she would need a second mastectomy, hysterectomy, chemo and radiation. In her shared hospital room, a fellow patient—fresh from a lumpectomy—heard the bad news, called out “Hey friend,” and offered reassurance (“They’re really good at breast cancer”), a marijuana cookie and an all-night conversation about surf days, parenthood, past mistakes and laughter so loud nurses intervened. Though they later lost contact, that transformative night taught her that seeking and accepting strangers’ kindness sustains hope.

articles.title: Readers reply: Why aren’t more animals hermaphrodites?
articles.trailText: The long-running series in which readers answer other readers’ questions on subjects ranging from trivial flights of fancy to profound scientific and philosophical concepts
articles.summary: Contributors note that hermaphroditism—either simultaneous or sequential—occurs extensively across invertebrates, many fish and angiosperms, overturning the idea that it’s rare. Vertebrates tend toward gonochorism because specialising as one sex slashes the metabolic cost of maintaining dual reproductive systems, optimises gamete production and parental investment, and enhances efficiency when mates are abundant. Ecological factors like resource availability, lifespan, viviparity versus oviparity and historical evolutionary chance further shape whether species evolve hermaphroditic or separate-sex strategies.

articles.title: Harriet Webb looks back: ‘Being told by a drama teacher that I needed to lose 10 stone was the making of me’
articles.trailText: The actor on her wonderful auntie Pat, being inspired by Michaela Coel and Danny Dyer, and her ‘terrible’ arm tattoo
articles.summary: Lancashire-born Harriet Webb (b.1986) credits her art-teacher aunt Pat for nurturing her storytelling and creativity. After an optimistic childhood in Arkholme, she trained at LIPA, where a tutor’s demand that she lose 10 stone only strengthened her resolve to own her body and talent. Webb’s early credits included Plebs, White Gold and The Split, but her breakthrough came as Theodora in Michaela Coel’s I May Destroy You (2020). She now stars as Shannon in Channel 4’s Big Boys and Kirsty in Sky’s Mr Bigstuff, drawing inspiration from Coel, Danny Dyer and Ryan Sampson, and embracing a ‘provocatively kind’ persona and unshakeable self-belief.

articles.title: Dining across the divide: ‘I said Trump’s a bit of a despot and shouldn’t have had a state visit to the UK’
articles.trailText: One’s a Keir Starmer believer, the other a reluctant Labour voter. Could this GP and teacher agree on public sector pay rises and Andy Burnham?
articles.summary: Brighton GP Joe and London teacher Stuart meet at Liu Xiaomian Carnaby to bridge their political differences over bao buns and noodles. Joe supports Keir Starmer’s use of royal flattery to influence Trump’s UK state visit, while Stuart labels Trump a despot and argues against pomp. They agree public-sector funding should bolster core services over personal pay, with Stuart viewing teachers’ 22% rise as fair and Joe prioritizing resource investment. Both critique union strikes, debate Andy Burnham’s ambitions and toast a “Fresh Start” cocktail.

articles.title: This is how we do it: ‘When his grandma heard us having sex, she asked if we’d been “having a fun dance” upstairs’
articles.trailText: Living with elderly grandparents has helped Zach and Luna with the cost of living crisis – but not their sex life
articles.summary: Luna (23) and Zach (25) moved in with Zach’s elderly grandparents six months ago to care for them and escape rising rents. Their makeshift bedroom, once Zach’s mother’s childhood room, is tiny, with glow-in-the-dark stars and a creaky headboard that betrays their four-times-a-week sex life. Spontaneous, playful intimacy—Luna in cat ears under Zach’s desk, glow-dance excuses for too-loud moans—coexists with caregiving duties: bandages, stairlift beeps and crossword invitations interrupt private moments. Despite fatigue, they cherish physical tenderness, financial relief and the daily reminders of life’s fragility, deepening their bond and envisioning a future family.

articles.title: Why do we yawn? It’s almost certainly not for the reason you think
articles.trailText: Given that we’ve literally grown up with them, we often know surprisingly little about how our bodies work. This new series aims to fill the gaps
articles.summary: Yawning, seen across vertebrates, was long thought to boost oxygen but studies disprove this. Instead, jaw gaping and deep inhalation stretch blood vessels, increasing arterial flow and venous return in the skull, and inhaled air cools brain tissue. Thermoregulation theory explains why moderate warmth raises yawn frequency and why some conditions trigger excess yawning. The arousal-change hypothesis suggests yawns help switch between brain states and may circulate cerebrospinal fluid. Contagious yawning likely arises from mirror neurons or aids group coordination by synchronizing alertness. Evolved functions may overlap—brain cooling, circulatory adjustment and alertness shifts—and continual yawning thus supports optimal brain function.

articles.title: My friends keep leaving me out, but don’t like it if I do the same to them | Ask Annalisa Barbieri
articles.trailText: It sounds as if your friend is projecting her own unhappiness on to you. Don’t keep apologising, because that just feeds into her need for control
articles.summary: A 17-year-old in her final school year describes how she and her best friend B have been repeatedly excluded by friends C and D. After feeling controlled and unvalued by C—who nonetheless accuses them of exclusion—they seek advice from psychologist Prof. Alessandra Lemma via columnist Annalisa Barbieri. Lemma diagnoses C’s behaviour as narcissistic projection, warns the letter-writer to stop apologising, protect the healthy friendship with B and accept that C may be an unsustainable relationship. Barbieri affirms the writer’s self-worth and emotional intelligence, urging liberation by prioritising reciprocal bonds over toxic dynamics.

articles.title: Start small, keep a log, picture the end result: 17 experts’ top tips on how to stay motivated
articles.trailText: Need to psych yourself up for the gym or to blitz your to-do list? Experts including Marie Kondo to Diana Nyad reveal how they keep going when things get tough
articles.summary: Life & Style article offers 17 experts’ motivation hacks. Long-distance swimmer Diana Nyad conjures a desert survival fantasy to power through workouts. Marie Kondo sparks momentum with tiny tidying sprees. Iwan Carrington races songs to blitz chores; Austin Kleon reads obituaries to remind himself of life’s brevity. Katy Milkman rewards exercise with binge-watch treats, Chrissie Wellington takes micro-steps and logs progress. Dr Radha Modgil tackles procrastination by naming fears, Cal Newport tracks deep-work hours, and Adriene Mishler engages cross-sensory cues. Additional tips include lucky charms, device-free walks, 15-minute focus sprints and visualizing end results.

articles.title: Marriage getting you down? Can I interest you in a year-long break? | Polly Hudson
articles.trailText: The Amish tradition of ‘rumspringa’ gives teenagers time away from their families so they can explore worldly pleasures before knuckling down to life. Sound appealing?
articles.summary: Polly Hudson proposes a “Long-Term Relationship Rumspringa” inspired by the Amish rite—an agreed year apart to test marriages amid 42% UK divorce, allowing couples after 15–20 years together to live separately and explore forbidden behaviors. Eligibility is earned, not for newlyweds. On reunion, spouses simultaneously reveal decisions on staying together or divorcing, avoiding polite deadlock, and those recommitting can renew vows—ideally reigniting appreciation or clarifying the grass-is-greener reality.

articles.title: The moment I knew: I found their pyjamas under my pillow and felt butterflies
articles.trailText: After initially ghosting Nic, Gemma Foster-Wisdom realised she’d found ‘forever love’ when a little gesture gave her an incredible feeling
articles.summary: After ending a mismatched three-year hetero relationship, 27-year-old Gemma switches her Hinge preferences to women and matches with Australian speech pathologist Nic (they/them). Their first pub date is awkward, Gemma ghosts Nic, then apologizes and reconnects over a Covid-era socially distanced chat. A month later, she discovers Nic’s Vegemite-print pyjamas deliberately left under her pillow—a small gesture that gives her butterflies and convinces her she’s found ‘forever love.’ When Nic prepares to return to Australia, Gemma follows; they marry, buy a flat in Sydney’s inner west, adopt a cavoodle named Billie, and dream of starting a family on the coast together.

articles.title: A cloak, some monsters and a bicycle: Marguerite O’Molloy’s best phone picture
articles.trailText: A spooky scene in a Dublin shopfront – and a chance reflection – make for a surprising and unsettling shot
articles.summary: In Dublin’s Costume boutique on Castle Market, Marguerite O’Molloy stumbled on a Halloween window display of monsters and a bicycle. Captured on her phone and rendered in black-and-white via the Provoke Camera app with slight exposure tweaks in Snapseed, the image features an unedited passerby in a cloak-like coat whose backward glance adds scale and eeriness. The bicycle evokes The Wizard of Oz’s flying witch, and O’Molloy later chose Ruby Slipper red nail polish to complement the spooky scene.

articles.title: How do hot air balloons steer and what makes frogs ‘ribbit’? The kids’ quiz
articles.trailText: Five multiple-choice questions – set by children – to test your knowledge, and a chance to submit your own junior brainteasers for future quizzes
articles.summary: Children test their STEM know-how with five multiple-choice questions—exploring how pilots steer hot air balloons by adjusting buoyancy and wind currents, why frogs ‘ribbit’ to communicate, plus quiz items on plant survival, weather phenomena and animal behavior. Questions were crafted by young quizmasters for Everything Under the Sun, a kids’ podcast and quiz series hosted by Molly Oldfield. Readers can submit their own junior brainteasers for future rounds. The article also spotlights Oldfield’s educational book series, Everything Under the Sun and its quiz and travel spin-offs.

articles.title: Short-term hibernation in animals is known as what? The Saturday quiz
articles.trailText: From a diagonal sleeve and a front fastening sweater to Tennyson, test your knowledge with the Saturday quiz
articles.summary: The Saturday quiz presents fifteen trivia questions spanning animal behaviour, history, culture and geography: from Disney’s ‘go away green’ paint and Miss Shepherd in Alan Bennett’s Lady in the Van to the term for short-term hibernation (torpor), the guillotine, Jackie Kennedy Onassis, acute mountain sickness in mountaineering, Jordan’s ruling House of Hashim, the Johnnie Walker Striding Man, Welsh national park summits, Pirates of the Caribbean film titles, grand slam courts, non-euro EU currencies, UK channel launch dates, Crimean War references in Tennyson’s verse, and David Hockney’s double portraits.

articles.title: Blind date: ‘I was sweating quite a lot for the first five minutes’
articles.trailText: Daniel, a civil servant, meets Isla, a lawyer. Both are 29
articles.summary: Civil servant Daniel (29) and Australian lawyer Isla (29) meet on a Guardian-arranged blind date at Da Long Yi Hotpot, London W1. Smiley and chatty, they connect over jobs, British vs Australian humour, tiramisu, lido swims and side gigs (pub quizzes, DJ). Daniel’s nerves cause sweaty first minutes; Isla appreciates his warmth. They ditch table manners to cook hotpot, share a hug instead of a kiss on the train home. Rated 7.5/10 and 8/10, they plan a drink post-article and agree Mondays are poorly timed.

articles.title: Tim Dowling: after a year of ignoring each other, the cat and the dog have declared war
articles.trailText: We arrive home from holiday to discover our pets scrapping constantly. Are they enjoying themselves? It’s hard to tell
articles.summary: Tim Dowling returns from holiday to find his cat and dog—longstanding roommates—engaged in relentless, whether-playful or escalating scuffles across his family’s commandeered, screen-filled kitchen. Overseen by his sons and his oldest’s girlfriend, who also debate stalled scaffolding, the pets only pause near feeding time, orchestrating meows and barks to manipulate an early dinner. Dowling vacillates between his unheated garden office and refereeing the snarling duels under autumn’s falling leaves. Even the tortoise casts a sorrowful glance at their perpetual war before curling up for sleep.

articles.title: ‘Every time I step outside, the first thing on my mind is my forehead’: the women getting hair transplants
articles.trailText: A growing wave of women are turning to what was once seen as a surgery for men, hoping it will cure their self-consciousness about high hairlines and thinning crowns. But with treatments costing thousands and bodge jobs common, is it suitable – or even safe?
articles.summary: Women like 27-year-old Aria and 69-year-old Harriet are increasingly turning to hair transplants—once a male preserve—to combat high hairlines, thinning crowns and the shame of female hair loss. Global female procedures rose 16.5% between 2021 and 2024, yet quality varies: FUT and FUE cost £3,000–10,000 and carry risks from DIY clinics to botched jobs and scarring. Many seek cheaper Turkish “hair tourism” driven by celebrity endorsements. Experts stress ruling out medical causes, stabilising loss and choosing accredited surgeons. While successful transplants can look natural and boost confidence, the boom underscores societal pressure on women’s appearance and calls for safer, regulated solutions.

articles.title: No sex please: a lavender marriage suits us | Letters
articles.trailText: Letters: Readers respond to article about the increase in people seeking matrimony centred on companionship and connection rather than sex
articles.summary: Readers share firsthand accounts of ‘lavender marriages’—unions founded on companionship, legal security and spiritual connection rather than sexual intimacy. Jenny Day, in her 60s, describes three successive platonic marriages—first a heterosexual union, then a same-sex civil partnership, and now a single-sex marriage—all misread by others as sexual. A second writer recounts cohabiting with her best friend and cat, facing exclusion in mixed company and societal discomfort toward single, nonsexual partnerships. Correspondents highlight legal perks, patriarchal biases and even a literary example by E. F. Benson.

articles.title: Tigest Girma: ‘I was like – Hey, do you want black vampires? And they were like – Yeah, we want’
articles.trailText: The Melbourne writer topped the New York Times bestseller list with her debut fantasy novel – but that doesn’t stop doubt creeping in
articles.summary: Tigest Girma, 27, Ethiopian-Australian writer based in Melbourne’s Docklands, became a New York Times bestselling author before 27 with Immortal Dark, a YA fantasy weaving Ethiopian mythology and ‘black vampires’ at Uxlay University. Inspired by cultural othering after migrating at 13 and lacking representation in paranormal romances, she penned a trilogy born during Covid lockdown via a one-line tweet. Critics initially rejected her black-led fantasy, but the debut topped charts and paved way for sequel Eternal Ruin on Oct 28. Girma still battles self-doubt yet embraces failure as fuel for creativity and authenticity.

articles.title: ‘Am I doing this right?’: how to master the lost art of flirting
articles.trailText: Making a romantic connection with a stranger in real life means levelling up one’s game. The good news is, it is possible to learn how to be a good flirt
articles.summary: Young adults today flirt less face-to-face, leaning on apps; experts say social skills like flirting can be rebuilt through “exposure therapy”—small daily interactions—to practice pre-approach eye contact, modest specific compliments, reciprocal body language and sustained gaze. Workshops like Laugeson’s Peers program outline dos and don’ts: hold/avert/return your look, avoid generic praise, respect personal boundaries (“once ask, twice check”). Flirting is about sharing energy, ambiguity and mutual pleasure: dance enthusiastically, women can initiate, straight men signal safety by stepping back. Rejection is part of the game; persistence builds confidence.

articles.title: Clean lines and a connection with nature: the modernist beach house jutting out over a Scottish loch
articles.trailText: A couple’s dream home on Scotland’s rocky west coast is an audacious, Frank Lloyd Wright-inspired feat of architecture
articles.summary: On Loch Long’s rugged Rosneath peninsula, architects Stuart Cameron and homeowner John MacKinnon converted a derelict MoD site into Rock Cove, a single-storey, Frank Lloyd Wright-inspired modernist beach house. Cantilevered over rocks, its low-slung box of Kebony timber and triple-glazed walls maximizes views while providing step-free living for retirement. Interiors include a generous open kitchen-living area, four modest ensuite bedrooms opening onto a terrace, and a 2m-wide corridor showcasing Aboriginal art. Durable Dekton worktops and modular Ikea furnishings underpin future-proofed design. Rock Cove has won awards and is available to rent via holidaycottages.co.uk.

articles.title: Plant wild tulips, rather than showier varieties, for a meadowy garden look come spring
articles.trailText: Big, blousy show-stoppers are all very well, but species tulips offer longer-term benefits and come in array of hot colours
articles.summary: After moving to a blank garden, the writer opts for wild species tulips over annual showy hybrids, citing their naturalising habit, self-seeding, longer bloom cycles and meadowy aesthetic. Originating in mountainous regions, species tulips (e.g. T. saxatilis’s lilac-and-yolk display, Barbie-pink T. humilis ‘Eastern Star’, duck-beak yellow T. sylvestris, soft-white T. turkestanica or antique-flush T. ‘Danique’) thrive in well-drained soil—ideal in gravel, rock gardens or sand-amended containers. Plant in December in the sun; avoid overwatering; foliage emerging early will survive frost.

articles.title: Experience: I’ve been on television more than 2,500 times (but you won’t know my face)
articles.trailText: My work as a TV and film extra was a dream come true. My look – skinny and not too good-looking – was in high demand
articles.summary: Background actor Peter Sommers has clocked over 2,500 TV and film appearances since 1998, from period gentry to newsreader cameos on soaps (Emmerdale, Hollyoaks, Coronation Street) and detective series. After retail jobs he joined a Doctor Who spin-off, turned extra to pay more, even featuring in Sherlock Holmes 2 and The Woman in Black. On the set of Doctors he met fellow extra Neilum, married in 2013, and had daughter India. Transitioning to runner then first assistant director on Doctors, he’s now a Netflix filmmaker and author, while his wife runs a chaperone agency. He remains open to great background roles.

articles.title: I am content being single. How do I make people understand that I’m happy as I am? | Leading questions
articles.trailText: Anyone whose life deviates from mainstream expectations gets this, writes advice columnist Eleanor Gordon-Smith . Perhaps you could play with different ways to describe it
articles.summary: A 54-year-old woman, content after 14 years single and a brief second marriage, is frustrated by friends’ and family’s insistence she ‘needs’ a partner. She cherishes her independence, balanced work-life and time with daughters and grandchildren, yet unsolicited advice leaves her doubting herself. Advice columnist Eleanor Gordon-Smith suggests reframing how she describes her life—turning an ‘empty house’ into ‘peaceful sanctuary’ or mornings alone into ‘calm confidence’—so that others see her reality through her own, affirming language and respect her happiness as complete.

articles.title: I know I should stop writing about zips. But I’ve just suffered another outrage | Adrian Chiles
articles.trailText: When an expensive suitcase refused to close, all my old frustration came flooding back. Don’t tell me to pull myself together, writes Adrian Chiles
articles.summary: Adrian Chiles admits it's been 267 days since his last zip-related tirade, but a broken zipper on a pricey suitcase—its failure striking just two weeks shy of the guarantee's expiry—has reignited his rage. Though the manufacturer replaced the bag, Chiles refuses to discard the crippled original, vowing never to yield to "zip tyranny." He spotlights Japanese maker YKK—producer of half the world's zips—and its new AiryString zipper, a century-first redesign that jettisons conventional fabric tape, hailed by a fabric expert as "genius and long overdue."

articles.title: Thursday news quiz: Jailhouse books, museum trouble and an unexpected bear
articles.trailText: Test yourself on topical news trivia, pop culture and general knowledge every Thursday. How will you fare?
articles.summary: This Thursday’s Guardian news quiz (#220) challenges readers with 16 topical trivia questions drawn from recent quirky headlines: from incarcerated politicians posing with “jailhouse books,” controversies at a national museum, to a surprise bear roaming a seaside town. Covering pop culture, current affairs and general knowledge, it rewards both news junkies and casual quiz-takers. Participants can debate disputed answers in the comments and share scores. If you spot an egregious error in a joking question, you may lodge a reasoned complaint. Prefer cinema? Watch Landslide by Nightbus instead. Allons-y!

articles.title: Get your jabs, don’t oversleep, don’t be too keen to go to work: GPs’ tips for battling winter illnesses
articles.trailText: What’s worse than being wet, chilly and light-deprived? Being wet, chilly, light-deprived and sick. Here are 14 ways to stave off colds and the flu – or bounce back if it’s already too late
articles.summary: As temperatures drop and daylight wanes, GPs emphasize a three-legged stool of sleep, nutrition and exercise, plus flu and COVID vaccinations, basic hygiene, and vitamin D supplementation. Fill your medicine cabinet with painkillers, nasal sprays and lozenges, hydrate, rest and treat symptoms with paracetamol or ibuprofen when needed. Eat protein, vibrant produce, complex carbs and healthy fats. Guard mental health with regular daylight, structure, social contact and moderation in alcohol. Don’t oversleep or rush back to work; see a doctor if fever, breathlessness or cough persist.

articles.title: You be the judge: should my sister buy new crockery and cutlery?
articles.trailText: Fiona says her sister should update the tableware in their shared flat, but Mara believes her mismatched aesthetic is authentic and sustainable. You get to twist the knife
articles.summary: Sisters Fiona and Mara clash over their shared flat’s tableware. Fiona, 29, finds Mara’s mismatched, chipped plates and blunt knives chaotic and unadult, wanting clean, cohesive crockery to elevate dinners and impress guests. Artist Mara, 33, treasures each piece’s history, views matching sets as sterile and wasteful, and champions sustainability and personal style. Guardian readers offer split advice—suggesting compromises like buying separate cutlery—or urge Fiona to move out. A poll asks: should Mara replace her well-worn collection with new, matching kitchenware?

articles.title: ‘The pressure to get your old body back is immense’: the new mothers driven to weight-loss jabs
articles.trailText: The NHS warns against using GLP-1s while breastfeeding – for the baby’s sake as well as the mother’s. But how much does that count when they’re so readily available and there’s so much pressure to ‘bounce back’?
articles.summary: Amid intense societal pressure to ‘bounce back’, UK mothers are turning to GLP-1 weight-loss injections while breastfeeding despite NHS warnings on milk quality and infant health. Interviews with new mums (Lydia, Melanie) reveal yo-yo dieting histories and hazards of private providers dispensing Mounjaro/Ozempic unchecked. Experts like Dr Toledano and the Breastfeeding Network warn of unknown drug transfer into breastmilk, risks to infant growth, milk supply cessation and postnatal depression. Breastfeeding Network enquiries about weight-loss jabs rose 145% in a year, prompting calls for stricter oversight and support.

articles.title: Work out while you work? Ten strength-building office exercises you can do in everyday clothes
articles.trailText: Sitting down all day is bad for our health. So can micro-movements – three minutes at a time – help us get fitter?
articles.summary: This guide tackles the health risks of prolonged sitting by recommending ten discreet, strength-building micro-workouts you can slot into your workday in everyday attire. Backed by Australian, UK and WHO inactivity data, it suggests three-minute routines—calf raises, wall sits, one-leg balances, step-ups on stairs, incline push-ups, makeshift farmers’ carries, leg marches, lateral flexions, body-weight squats and slow desk walking. Pilates instructors and exercise physiologists advocate habit stacking to break up sedentary time, meet activity guidelines and lower chronic disease risk with gradual, sustainable progress.

articles.title: The secret lives of autograph hunters: ‘Donald Trump was really hard to get’
articles.trailText: Why do so many people spend their time at stage doors and sending out requests for signatures? Those who have collected thousands of autographs explain the thrill
articles.summary: Three autograph hunters describe their passion: Andrew Broughton, who began aged 13 after Peter Cushing sent signed stills, now has 10,000 autographs including royalty from Queen Elizabeth II to King Charles, all US presidents (Trump was 'really hard to get'), Brigitte Bardot and Muhammad Ali, and even attended Charles and Camilla’s wedding. Jason Thanos turned celebrity signatures into a £75–£4,000 memorabilia business by waiting outside premieres and festivals for stars like Jolie, Stallone ('keep punching'), and once earned £5,000 for Schwarzenegger. Clare Hodges, who sends 30 letters a month, finds comfort in meeting icons amid personal loss. Collecting blends history, fandom and adrenaline.

articles.title: A moment that changed me: I gave up small talk for a month – and the world came alive
articles.trailText: I was fed up with discussing the weather, so I started to ask unexpected questions. The conversations that resulted were revelatory
articles.summary: Fed up with weather and pleasantries, writer Claire Eastham spent a month ditching routine chatter and posing offbeat questions—asking about star signs, school art teachers or favorite seasons. The experiment sparked richer, candid exchanges with strangers who revealed passions from drag performing to beekeeping. Though a few found it odd, most welcomed the shift. Eastham concludes that while small talk eases us in, we can rewrite its script for deeper, more authentic human connection.

articles.title: Three affordable ways to keep your house running during a power outage
articles.trailText: You don’t need a $10,000 Tesla Powerwall to survive the next storm. These three devices offer peace of mind and a chance to help others
articles.summary: Consumer journalist Alan Truly outlines three affordable backup power solutions to weather multi-day outages without a $10k Powerwall. He relies on a Jackery Explorer 2000 v2 (2,042Wh, 2.2kW output, $699–799) paired with two foldable 100W solar panels to support cooking and small appliances, a Twing 1000W inverter tapped into his Prius C to extend runtime, and a compact Maxpeedingrods 2300W inverter generator ($500) as a last resort. This modular setup minimizes fuel use, fits in a car trunk, lets you share power, and integrates with basic storm prep.

articles.title: ‘Chasing the ideal gut’: poop-tracking cameras claim to give health insights. Are they necessary?
articles.trailText: Products like Dekoda can run up to $600 and photograph your every bowel movement – but who owns that data?
articles.summary: Kohler’s Dekoda ($599 plus subscription) and Austin startup Throne ($319) install cameras in toilets to capture and analyze stool via proprietary algorithms and the Bristol scale. Fingerprint activation triggers LED illumination; images are encrypted and uploaded to Kohler’s cloud. Although marketed as privacy-first, Kohler Health isn’t HIPAA-covered and shares anonymized data with unspecified partners, raising ownership and commercial‐use concerns. Dietitians caution that obsessing over an “ideal gut” may overlook basic fiber intake and the microbiome’s natural fluctuations—free Bristol chart tracking remains a viable alternative.

articles.title: As eastern Australia prepares to swelter, here’s how to protect your pets in a heatwave
articles.trailText: Leave more than one bowl of water out and place freezing treats in puzzle toys to help keep your pets cool in scorching conditions
articles.summary: With eastern Australia set to hit near 40 °C, RSPCA NSW vet Dr Liz Arnott advises pet owners to provide multiple bowls of cool water, ample shade and access to indoor, tiled spaces. Use fans, wading pools and frozen treats in puzzle toys to lower core temperatures; small mammals benefit from frozen water bottles in their enclosures and good ventilation. Schedule dog walks for early morning or evening to avoid hot pavement and at-risk brachycephalic breeds. Monitor for heavy panting, drooling, weakness or vomiting, wet the coat to cool down and consult a vet if heat stress appears.

articles.title: Houseplant clinic: what are the brown patches on my prickly pear?
articles.trailText: Corking is the most likely culprit, but it’s possible it could be scale insects or fungus. Here’s how to check
articles.summary: Raised brown patches on a prickly pear cactus are most likely corking, a natural process where the lower stem hardens and turns bark-like with age. It poses no harm but can be mistaken for scale insects or fungal spots. Scale appears as uniform, removable bumps, whereas corking is inseparable from the tissue. No treatment is needed if growth continues at the tips. Maintain bright light, well-draining soil and cautious watering; corking simply reflects maturity.

articles.title: I fell at the top of a mountain – and knew I had to haul my broken body down or die in the snow
articles.trailText: While navigating a steep trail, Jean Muenchrath lost her grip. She was horrifically injured, with a broken spine, shattered tailbone, pubic bone and hip fractures, internal bleeding, a head wound and one on her buttock that turned gangrenous. There was no choice but to get home ...
articles.summary: In May 1982, 22-year-old ranger Jean Muenchrath summited Mount Whitney with her partner Ken when a storm forced a steep descent. Ken fell 800ft unhurt but Jean broke her spine, pelvis, tailbone and suffered internal bleeding and gangrenous wounds. Trapped by blizzard, she spent three nights in a cramped tent vowing to live, then embarked on a five-day descent—sometimes crawling—while Ken carried gear until they reached help. Told she’d never hike again, she defied odds: recovered, trekked the Himalayas, founded Nepal tours, endured chronic pain through meditation, and finally forgave herself.

articles.title: Diwali celebrations in Australia: ‘It’s about sharing our joy and excitement’
articles.trailText: Lights, fireworks and feasting are staples of Hinduism’s festival of light, which hails the triumph of goodness over evil
articles.summary: Narender Kumar and family, who migrated from Saudi Arabia to Box Hill, Melbourne in mid-2024, celebrate Diwali by lighting diyas, sharing sweets like kaju katli and fireworks to honor Lakshmi on the festival’s third day. Across Australia, where Hinduism is the fastest-growing religion and Indians are the second-largest migrant group, councils host Diwali events — Rockdale and Wyndham festivals, Marvel Stadium and Federation Square gatherings, Opera House light-ups, and Blacktown’s decorating contest. Kumar lauds multicultural support, workplace flexibility and family reunions, calling Diwali a shared celebration of light, prosperity and community.

articles.title: Protecting the crown jewels in pilates classes | Brief letters
articles.trailText: Brief letters: Pilates and the male psyche | Targeted for tax | Hot designs | Carving up the US
articles.summary: The letters begin with Tom Stubbs reflecting on being the sole man in Pilates classes and how cues like instructors whispering “crown jewels” underscore female-focused language that alienates men. Sandra Norburn finds it jarring that relief at Rachel Reeves’s fair-shoulder tax proposal is followed by the chancellor targeting disabled car schemes. Elaine Steane admires a double-height garden room in a retrofitted almshouse but urges external blinds ahead of a predicted 2°C warming. John Illingworth calls on reporters to ask Donald Trump which states he’d cede for peace if the US faced invasion.

articles.title: Our defective lounge was replaced with a model $200 cheaper. Can we get the difference refunded?
articles.trailText: Consumer law is on your side here, Australian policy expert Kat George writes. If the business won’t cooperate, call the Office of Fair Trading
articles.summary: Bronwyn in Queensland had a faulty leather lounge exchanged for a cheaper replacement and the store refuses to refund the $200 price gap. Under Australian Consumer Law, consumers with major faults are entitled to an identical or equal-value replacement or a refund of the difference. She should write to the retailer citing her consumer guarantees, include receipts and assessments, and if they still resist, contact the Queensland Office of Fair Trading or escalate to the ACCC or QCAT, though tribunal costs may outweigh the amount.

articles.title: Feel like your mind and body are separate? Here’s how life changes when we become whole
articles.trailText: When I was younger, I valued my body only for what it could do for me. A quick jog was enough to make me see where I’d been going wrong
articles.summary: Moya Sarner, an NHS psychotherapist, recounts rediscovering regular running after high cholesterol prompted exercise for health rather than appearance or performance. She explores how her body–mind relationship has shifted: initially viewing her body as a machine to shape or suppress emotions, she cites Freud’s idea of developmental integration and describes psychoanalysis unearthing how repressed feelings manifested as indigestion and acid reflux. Naming and feeling those emotions resolved symptoms. Now, running feels less pressured and more holistic—a sign of respect for her body–mind unity and the preciousness of life.

articles.title: The one change that worked: I had terrible insomnia – until I hit upon a gory solution
articles.trailText: I had tried elaborate mind games, herbal teas and even a military method. Nothing worked. So I gave in, tuned into some macabre podcasts and had a very surprising reaction
articles.summary: After years of battling insomnia with pills, herbal teas, elaborate mind games and even an SAS-inspired military breathing technique, the author finally gave up trying to force sleep. Instead of counting sheep, they turned on true-crime podcasts—immersing themselves in grisly tales of cults, home break-ins and chainsaw-wielding killers. To their surprise, the passive, macabre distraction quietly lulls them to sleep. Their experience suggests that over-effort can backfire, and sometimes the key to restful slumber is to stop obsessing and let a gripping, mindless narrative do the work.

articles.title: Why men should be doing a lot more pilates  | Letters
articles.trailText: Letters: Tim Heavisides hails the benefits of pilates for rugby players, and Margaret Evans highlights the knee-injuries sustained in walking football
articles.summary: Tim Heavisides recounts his six-year experience of Pilates, lamenting that men rarely join women-dominated classes, and credits Pilates’ core-strengthening benefits for faster injury recovery and sustained fitness in rugby, urging men to follow George Ford’s lead. Margaret Evans warns that walking football poses a high risk of knee damage—common enough to fuel hospital admissions—advising rest and gentle physio with six-to-12-month recovery, while lamenting her 78-year-old husband’s absence from its social benefits.

articles.title: The rise of the sleep data nerds: ‘The harder you try, the harder it is to sleep’
articles.trailText: Wearable sleep trackers may help you measure hours asleep but experts ask how accurate they are, how useful the data is and even what good sleep looks like
articles.summary: Consumer wearable sleep trackers—from rings and watches to under-mattress sensors—are booming as users seek data on sleep duration, stages and disturbances. Experts warn their algorithms, based on movement, heart rate and temperature, lack brainwave monitoring and often misclassify sleep, risking ‘orthosomnia’: obsession with optimization. While guidelines recommend seven to nine hours, true sleep quality—stage distribution and fragmentation—remains hard to define. Nonetheless, nightly data over time can reveal personal sleep influencers such as evening exercise or alcohol, prompting behavior tweaks, though trackers are not substitutes for clinical polysomnography or diagnostic tools.

articles.title: The kindness of strangers: a gang of scary-looking youths stepped in to save me from being mugged
articles.trailText: I was having some trouble getting the car door to open when I suddenly felt hands around my neck. A voice behind me said ‘give me your purse’
articles.summary: In 1986, a psychologist recounts how, late one night in a supermarket car park, she was grabbed at knifepoint while retrieving her dog. In a trauma-driven ‘ocean moment’ she screamed for help, and a feared-looking group of youths—sporting safety-pin earrings—emerged, chased off her attacker, stayed to comfort her, escorted her to the police station, then vanished. The episode taught her not to judge by appearances, restored her faith in humanity and highlighted the power of stranger kindness.

articles.title: US couples are moving in together sooner to save money: ‘The world isn’t made for singles’
articles.trailText: Studies show more adults are willing to fast-track cohabitation to split expenses. What happens if you want to break up?
articles.summary: US couples are increasingly fast-tracking cohabitation to split soaring rents and living costs. Apartments.com finds 25% move in within six months, 33% to save on rent; Kinsey/DatingNews surveys show nearly one in four singles—38% of Gen Z—do so for finances. Experts warn of “financial coupling” when cost barriers delay breakups (55% stay longer) and note a gender gap in appetite for early move-ins. Meanwhile, many young women romanticize independent living, echoing the 1930s Live Alone and Like It ethos.

articles.title: Why aren’t more animals hermaphrodites?
articles.trailText: The long-running series in which readers answer other readers’ questions on subjects ranging from trivial flights of fancy to profound scientific and philosophical concepts
articles.summary: The Guardian’s readers tackle why hermaphroditism—common in snails, worms and many invertebrates—remains rare in vertebrates. They outline benefits of flexibility and reduced mate scarcity in hermaphrodites versus the specialized pressures in vertebrates: anisogamy leading to distinct sperm and egg roles, sexual selection favoring dimorphism, internal fertilization, parental investment patterns and developmental constraints. Vertebrate physiology and ecology lock in separate sexes despite the genetic diversity hermaphroditism offers, leaving the evolutionary trade-offs an enduring puzzle.

articles.title: The blood pressure secret: everything you need to know to improve yours – and live a longer, healthier life
articles.trailText: It is known as ‘the silent killer’, because many people suffer from high blood pressure without even being aware of it. Here is where your numbers should be, and how to change them for the better
articles.summary: Hypertension, a ‘silent killer’ responsible for 10 million deaths annually, affects 1.4 billion adults—600 million untreated. Healthy BP is 90/60–120/80 mmHg; 121/81–134/84 is ‘elevated’ and ≥135/85 ‘high.’ Accurate assessment uses multiple readings, bilateral-arm checks, home vs clinical thresholds (white-coat effect), ambulatory monitors and wearables. Management combines ACE inhibitors (e.g., ramipril), salt reduction (<6 g/day), weight and alcohol control, regular aerobic, resistance and isometric exercise (e.g., wall squats), and stress mitigation via meditation and breathwork. Early detection and intervention reduce risks of heart attack, stroke, kidney failure, vision loss and dementia.

articles.title: Huey Morgan looks back: ‘My father left when I was seven. Music was a way to derail those feelings of not being good enough’
articles.trailText: The musician on dealing with PTSD, his angry TV outburst, and why one radio station refused to play anything by Fun Lovin’ Criminals
articles.summary: Huey Morgan, born in 1968 in NYC, channelled the abandonment by his father and ADHD-fuelled hyperfocus into music—first forming a teenage band, then serving in the US Marines as an alternative to jail. After discharge, he co-founded Fun Lovin’ Criminals, whose platinum debut Come Find Yourself spawned “Scooby Snacks.” Battling PTSD with talk therapy and meditation, Morgan’s defiant stance against lip-sync demands once sidelined him from radio for five years. Now a BBC 6 Music host and author of memoir The Fun Lovin’ Criminal, he’s sober, married with a son, and lives by “courage is doing it scared.”

articles.title: Readers reply: what is the most common word in the world?
articles.trailText: The long-running series in which readers answer other readers’ questions on subjects ranging from trivial flights of fancy to profound scientific and philosophical concepts
articles.summary: Readers debate the world’s most common word beyond brand names. Corpus data show written English tops with “the”; European translations of that definite article rank highly, while languages like Irish lack direct yes/no equivalents. In speech and gestures, proposals include “la,” “like,” “mama,” “stop” and “eat.” Many argue “OK,” borrowed from 19th-century US slang, is globally ubiquitous. Pronouns (“I,” “you”), basic nouns (“people,” “time”) and the verb “have” also feature among top tokens.

articles.title: Dining across the divide: ‘We didn’t agree on immigration. She was almost conspiratorial’
articles.trailText: She thought he was naive; he thought she was too staunch on immigration. Would they find common ground on capitalism, Trump or nuclear power?
articles.summary: Lucas, 23, a Blackpool NHS worker and ex-Labour voter eyeing the Greens, joins 69-year-old Rose-Marie, a retired long-time Conservative, for dinner at Michael Wan’s Mandarin. Over duck pancakes, chilli prawns and wine, they sharply clash on immigration—Lucas as a proud multiculturalist, Rose-Marie warning of ‘out of control’ migration—but both back nuclear power. They spar on capitalism, climate responsibility and Trump (Lucas a fierce critic, Rose-Marie a reluctant admirer) yet leave dinner with mutual respect despite deep divides.

articles.title: This is how we do it: ‘When I tell other gay men we’re monogamous, it’s like I’ve said we have a strange kink’
articles.trailText: Jake tends to be submissive, while Leo is more dominant. Now they’re living in different countries, is long-distance love working out for them?
articles.summary: Jake (30) and Leo (29) reignited a decade-old techno-club romance during lockdown, bonding over family acceptance and deep chats. Despite Leo’s history of open relationships and Jake’s strict monogamy and submissive-bottom role, Jake insisted Leo end his prior relationship. They moved to Berlin—Jake grew curious about non-monogamy but found its “admin” unromantic. Now long-distance between London and Germany, they navigate mismatched energy levels, dominant/submissive dynamics and the pressure of infrequent visits. Honest communication about sex, routines and emotions fuels renewed intimacy, turning distance-induced anticipation into deeper compromise with hopes of reuniting permanently.

articles.title: I want to marry my girlfriend, but I’m worried it may upset my young son
articles.trailText: You are entitled to a relationship. Just make sure your son knows he won’t be loved any less and your girlfriend won’t replace his mother
articles.summary: A 44-year-old divorced father shares custody of his 7-year-old son and worries that marrying his long-term partner might upset his child, who hasn’t grasped that she’s his girlfriend. Therapist Lucy Fuller advises using clear, age-appropriate language, projecting confidence to avoid child anxiety, and explaining that the partner complements rather than replaces his mother. Emphasise love isn’t divided but multiplied, invite questions about their relationship and future marriage, and reassure the boy he remains central, noting children often focus on practical details.

articles.title: Should friendship really be a ‘one strike and you’re out’ deal?
articles.trailText: The idea of ditching friends if they err has become more and more popular in the last few years. But it’s important to recognise our own failings ...
articles.summary: Freelancer Polly Hudson reflects on a Mumsnet contributor who discovered her close friends booked theatre season tickets without her, felt disastrously excluded, then learnt their oversight was innocent. Though she labels them 'dead' to her, commenters urge forgiveness, noting everyone slips up. Hudson argues friendships shouldn’t be a ‘one strike and you’re out’ deal: minor thoughtlessness demands empathy, not isolation. She warns that excessive pruning of relationships risks loneliness, especially as 42% of US teens now turn to AI companions. Imperfect human bonds, she contends, are worth the mess and effort—and deserve more grace than robotic alternatives.

articles.title: The moment I knew: she made the life I’d overcomplicated suddenly straightforward
articles.trailText: As Air’s Moon Safari played in background, Andrew Stafford watched himself falling in love, in a new way
articles.summary: In April 2021, eight months post–open heart surgery and approaching fifty, Andrew Stafford joined Bumble, where he matched with Lisa, a follower of his late ragdoll cat, Priscilla. Their cautious courtship over wine, a mutual passion for birds and nature, and joint trips to far north Queensland fostered deep connection. One evening, as Air’s Moon Safari played, Stafford realized he was falling in love: what had felt overcomplicated suddenly seemed straightforward. Having both survived health challenges, they embraced life’s second chances, blended their cat families, and found in Lisa’s compassion and clear boundaries the stability Stafford had long underestimated.

articles.title: Pushy parents are ‘biggest problem in sports performance’, say psychologists
articles.trailText: Unsportsmanlike conduct in grassroots football and on the sidelines at school events is on the rise. How can parents support their child in the right way?
articles.summary: Sports psychologists warn pushy, shouty parents are the biggest problem in UK youth sport, with schools in south London banning spectators amid abuse toward officials and children. Chair Stephen Smith says parental pressure ‘freezes’ young athletes and worsened sideline behaviour is hampering grassroots football referees. Dr Matthew Cunliffe highlights the need for warm, consistent support rather than coaching pressure. While high-profile athletes like Raducanu, Williams sisters and Hamilton thrived under strict parenting, experts lament no organisation has stepped up to train parents in constructive support.

articles.title: Bristol’s backyard vineyards: foot-stomping grapes in the garden
articles.trailText: A small group of Bristol winemakers are harvesting vines from their allotments and garden terraces, part of a growing global movement of passionate urban vintners
articles.summary: In Bristol, a loose collective of four urban vintners—including documentary cameraman James Bayliss-Smith—tends hidden allotment and garden terraces to cultivate up to 150 vines each, forming ‘Grape Expectations.’ Bayliss-Smith’s 40 Polish-variety vines yield disease-resistant, chemical-free grapes, while Katy Grant’s rondo vines evoke Provence and Jo Scofield’s cliffside plot produces natural Rondo wine foot-stomped in her Georgian flat. Retiree Bob Reeve grows late-ripening Chardonnay despite mildew and badgers at ‘Badger Bluff.’ Affiliated with the Urban Vineyards Association, they champion minimal-intervention, wild-yeast fermentation, arguing urban viticulture boosts biodiversity, preserves green spaces, and reconnects communities through hands-on, sustainable winemaking.

articles.title: ‘Dad taught me not just to look at the world but to really see it’: Ariel Meyerowitz’s best phone picture
articles.trailText: The art adviser captured a portrait of her famous father – the photographer Joel Meyerowitz – as he pointed his camera at her during a visit to an exhibition
articles.summary: Ariel Meyerowitz, art adviser and daughter of renowned photographer Joel Meyerowitz, took her best phone picture during his New York visit to Ugo Rondinone’s The Rainbow Body exhibition, capturing her father as he aimed his camera at her and a vibrant sculpture. Drawing on childhood lessons editing slides with dad, she learned to "really see" relationships of color, place and emotion. She values their day in galleries, their art-historical debates, and praises the iPhone’s accurate color fidelity. He always sets aside at least one day to tour galleries with her, sharing his eloquent commentary on photography and art history.

articles.title: Do flamingos have a favourite leg to stand on? The kids’ quiz
articles.trailText: Five multiple-choice questions – set by children – to test your knowledge, and a chance to submit your own junior brainteasers for future quizzes
articles.summary: Quiz for children featuring five multiple-choice questions designed by kids, including whether flamingos have a preferred leg, plus general science and geography brainteasers. Presented by Molly Oldfield on her Everything Under the Sun podcast, it tests young readers’ curiosity and knowledge. Participants can submit their own junior puzzles for future quizzes. The article also highlights Oldfield’s books—Everything Under the Sun, the Everything Under the Sun Quiz Book and Everything Under the Sun: All Around the World—encouraging families to explore more child-friendly science and world facts.

articles.title: What links Jane Jacobs and Georges-Eugène Haussmann? The Saturday quiz
articles.trailText: From Viscri and Zalapatak to the 92 Club, test your knowledge with the Saturday quiz
articles.summary: A 15-question Saturday quiz testing wide-ranging trivia: natural history (Arctic tern migration), monarchy (Charles III’s properties in Transylvania), music history (Blue Öyster Cult’s heavy metal umlaut), film (the xenomorph in Alien), anatomy (pancreas), journalism (Anna Ford’s coined “body fascism”), football culture (visiting all 92 league grounds), Shakespeare in Turkey, urban planning (linking Jane Jacobs, Haussmann and other theorists), alpine skiing win records, Mona Lisa references across media, historic superguns, TV characters’ resurrections, hybrid fruits and wedding-anniversary gifts via Roman numerals and elements.

articles.title: Tim Dowling: I’m in Greece with my band and the weather’s awful … but I can’t complain
articles.trailText: The gig is at a literary festival, which makes me anxious. I’m never at ease among people who don’t suffer fools gladly
articles.summary: Columnist Tim Dowling describes joining his band to play at a literary festival in Greece, juggling a home holiday, flight logistics and banjo anxieties. Arriving amid unexpected storms, their opening event and taverna rehearsals are disrupted by rain and noise protests. They improvise rehearsals in a closed-seafront tavern before a hastily rescheduled gala-dinner gig on the quayside, narrowly winning over skeptical audiences and even those who petitioned to reinstate the local band. Despite downpours and looming deadlines at home, Dowling revels in the surreal festival camaraderie and insists, “I’m not complaining.”

articles.title: Blind date: ‘It was hard to know how to react to his enthusiasm for a Vegas wedding’
articles.trailText: Emma, 32, a doctor, meets Julien, 41, an advertising creative
articles.summary: Emma, 32, a hospital doctor, and Julien, 41, an advertising creative, meet for a Guardian blind date at Piccolino, London. Punctual and curious, they swap stories on handstands, radiography, London culture, Trumpism, Vegas weddings and Paul Mescal’s shorts. Emma found Julien’s enthusiasm for a Vegas wedding hard to react to; Julien praised her adventurous storytelling and manners. Conversation stayed engaging but chemistry lagged. They shared a friendly hug, no kiss or number swap. Emma felt their stars weren’t aligned; Julien sees no follow-up but would chat again if they crossed paths.

articles.title: An unbreakable lock? On your bike… | Brief letters
articles.trailText: Letters: Kryptonite cycle locks | BBC Sounds | Trump and gun control | Best job in the world
articles.summary: Brief Letters: Jon Blower of London challenges claims that Kryptonite locks can thwart angle grinders after his bike was stolen and the lock sawed through twice, with no police follow-up. Marilyn Rowley of Manchester admits to dozing off to In Our Time’s soothing discussion, only to be jarred awake by the BBC Sounds jingle. Stephen Chicken of Swinton taunts Trump over disarming Hamas, suggesting Americans hand over their firearms. John White of Nantwich praises the Guardian letters editor’s enviable role.

articles.title: Hamish Macdonald: ‘The experience of hosting Q+A was totally overwhelming’
articles.trailText: The ABC radio host talks about copping abuse, being driven, and the rise of political violence around the world
articles.summary: ABC host Hamish Macdonald describes relocating to Parramatta, enjoying local parkland encounters, and reflects on his foreign-correspondent years—from the London bombings to Gaddafi’s fall. Married in 2023 to Jacob Fitzroy, he balances introversion with ocean swims, mountain hikes and near-daily gym visits. Inspired by his Jindabyne upbringing and parents’ resilience and empathy, he candidly recalls the mental toll of hosting Q+A in 2020–21 amid sustained online abuse, which led to his departure. Now anchoring ABC Sydney Mornings and co-hosting Global Roaming, he warns that global unrest has brought new risks of political violence to Australia.

articles.title: How to protect your garden from an early frost
articles.trailText: Learning which species can tolerate a cold snap and how your patch reacts to different kinds of frost will serve veg growers well as autumn nights lengthen
articles.summary: Gardeners should monitor frost dates – first frost in autumn and last frost in spring – to schedule sowing and protect crops. Air frost (≤0°C air) and ground frost (≤0°C soil) both can burst plant cells, blackening or killing tender species like tomatoes, beans, lettuce and cucumbers, while hardy varieties—leeks, chard, cabbage, kale—survive or sweeten. Identify frost pockets in low spots; use fleece or move container-grown plants (e.g. cape gooseberries) into sheltered positions. Since forecasts predict only air temps, watch for cold, clear nights that trigger ground frost, and record frost dates or ask neighbours to refine planting plans.

articles.title: Pregnant women in England at ‘growing risk’ of serious injury in childbirth
articles.trailText: NHS figures show number of mothers sustaining third- or fourth-degree perineal tear has increased by 16% since 2020
articles.summary: NHS data show third- and fourth-degree perineal tears in England rose by 16%, from 25 to 29 per 1,000 births since June 2020, meaning nearly 3% of vaginal deliveries now result in obstetric anal sphincter injuries (OASI). These life-changing tears cause chronic pain, incontinence and PTSD. Experts link the increase to understaffed maternity units, inconsistent risk assessments, and older, larger mothers. Following high-profile litigation, the health secretary has launched a national maternity inquiry and taskforce, while the RCOG urges universal adoption of the OASI care bundle to better identify and manage at-risk women.

articles.title: Experience: I am the air guitar world champion
articles.trailText: For 60 seconds I gave everything – explosive energy, perfect mime and rock star charisma. I think I blacked out from shock when they said I’d won
articles.summary: Finland's The Angus (nicknamed Little Angus), a lifelong air-guitar enthusiast from Oulu whose parents helped launch the first contest in 1996, won the 2025 Air Guitar World Championship. After years of finals and a 2023 runner-up finish, she choreographed a 60-second, high-energy routine to Avenged Sevenfold, tied with Japanese champion Yuta Sudo-chan, then won an improvised air-off to Guns N' Roses' Sweet Child o' Mine. Her victory, Oulu's first Finnish title in 25 years, enshrines the community's Make air, not war ethos and propels her ambitions as a musician, filmmaker and bartender ahead of Oulu's 2026 cultural year.

articles.title: My sister-in-law won’t let anyone hold her new baby. It feels extreme. Is it? | Leading questions
articles.trailText: There could be so many different reasons behind this choice, writes advice columnist Eleanor Gordon-Smith . Maybe what you really mean is you feel hurt to be left out
articles.summary: A sibling complains that his sister-in-law refuses to let anyone hold her new baby beyond the parents—and occasional grandparent holds—and immediately removes the infant at the slightest cry. Advice columnist Eleanor Gordon-Smith lists possible reasons: infection control, overstimulation avoidance, postpartum anxiety or simply personal comfort. Despite relatives’ fear of bonding deficits or future social issues, the column stresses respecting the parents’ decision, focusing on building a trusting relationship, offering the emotional support she needs, and remembering professionals can address any developmental concerns, rather than confronting her over what feels extreme.

articles.title: Thursday news quiz: French reshuffles, naked cyclists and a heroic dog
articles.trailText: Test yourself on topical news trivia, pop culture and general knowledge every Thursday. How will you fare?
articles.summary: The Guardian’s 219th Thursday news quiz mixes topical trivia and pop culture questions, from French government reshuffles and streaking cyclists to a tale of a heroic dog. Known for its playful trolling and in-joke answers, this week’s edition challenges readers on general knowledge and current affairs. With no prizes at stake, participants are encouraged to debate any purported errors—provided they can prove their case—and to share their scores in the comments. Bonus points for choosing Howling Bells’ “Unbroken” as your soundtrack. Allons-y!

articles.title: A genuine treat for £1.60? Try the shortest railway line in Britain | Adrian Chiles
articles.trailText: There is an even shorter route in Germany, but that runs less frequently - which gives the shuttle train in my home town the moral victory
articles.summary: On his hometown’s shuttle between Stourbridge Junction and Stourbridge Town—the UK's shortest railway line covering under a mile in three minutes—Adrian Chiles pays £1.60, chats with crew who shuttle over 214 times daily along a 1-in-67 gradient, and hears they take pride in this “repetitive” work. He contrasts it with Germany’s Friedrichshafen Stadt–Hafen link—barely half a mile but only ~70 daily trips—crowned continental shortest. Chiles grants Stourbridge a “moral victory” for its superior frequency.

articles.title: You be the judge: should my housemates bring the bins in?
articles.trailText: Mohammed alleges that his flatmate Ben isn’t doing his bit when it comes to the garbage. You decide who is talking rubbish
articles.summary: Split-level flatmates Mohammed (Mo), Ben and Roisin share two wheelie bins with upstairs neighbours under an unspoken system: neighbours put bins out, Mo returns them. When Mo is away, Ben and Roisin often neglect bin duties—letting rubbish pile up, smell, stray waste accumulates, and angering neighbours. Roisin dismisses bins as a “man’s job”; Ben argues bins belong to the council anyway and sporadic lateness isn’t a problem. Guardian readers side with Mo, calling for a shared schedule and greater consideration in communal living.

articles.title: ‘A highly scheduled life doesn’t serve us’: has living ‘intentionally’ gone too far?
articles.trailText: Carefully planning your routine can feel good in a chaotic world – but experts say we should ‘choose when to choose’
articles.summary: On TikTok and Instagram ‘intentional living’ means planning every minute—from workouts to dinner—but psychologists argue excessive scheduling sacrifices spontaneity, adaptability and enjoyment. Sheila Liming, author of Hanging Out, champions unstructured social time, like listening to the radio or talking to strangers, to foster patience and relational diversity. Barry Schwartz warns that constant choice is exhausting and paradoxically undermines freedom: we should ‘choose when to choose’ by reserving intentionality for decisions that truly matter and relying on habits or friends’ advice for the rest. The ideal balance blends thoughtful planning with deliberate unintentionality.

articles.title: Cumulative social advantage: is this the secret to a long, happy, healthy life?
articles.trailText: High income levels are associated with slower ageing – but so is another factor that will cost you nothing at all. It just involves plenty of time spent hanging out with family, friends and neighbours ...
articles.summary: A new study on “cumulative social advantage” finds that robust social relationships—family ties, emotional support networks, community and religious participation—are linked to slower epigenetic aging, potentially delaying infirmity, disease and death. By dampening stress responses and systemic inflammation, these bonds may offer benefits comparable to high income and education. While the most effective forms of engagement remain unclear, sustained conversations and local involvement emerge as accessible, cost-free strategies for healthy longevity.

articles.title: I didn’t plan on a sausage dog but McKenzie nudged me back to hope | Debbie Elkind
articles.trailText: First-time dog owner Debbie Elkind was worried how she’d fare with her new dachshund. Then she fell in love with her ‘ridiculous, beautiful’ animal
articles.summary: First-time dog owner Debbie Elkind wasn’t looking for a long dog, but pandemic lockdown scrolling on PetRescue led her to adopt McKenzie, a wary dachshund with separation anxiety and a penchant for chasing cats, cars and skateboarders. After initial training jitters and a battle over bed placement, McKenzie’s midnight cuddles and daily antics became Debbie’s emotional lifeline through injury, depression and grief. Two years later, a second rescue, Elodie, joins the household—another rescue with a sad story and high-pitched yelp—completing Debbie’s unexpected but perfect ‘found family’ on eight legs.

articles.title: Don’t even think about decking! How to create a nature-friendly low-maintenance garden
articles.trailText: Garden getting you down? Tempted to just pave or concrete over the whole thing and put your feet up? There are more enjoyable and eco-friendly alternatives, from miniature meadows to giant borders
articles.summary: Facing muddy lawns, many Britons plan to pave or deck yards—potentially erasing 8% of private greenery by 2030—fueling flooding, heat spikes and biodiversity loss, plus worse mental health. RHS science director warns against impermeable surfaces, urging no more than 25% paving and planning permission above 5 m². Designers advocate 3×3 m seating zones on gravel or permeable pavers, lifting slabs to plant daisies or arch climbers, and incorporating thyme driveways, mini meadows cut just once yearly, gravel beds on jute liners, low-maintenance borders, robust shrubs, ornamental grasses, bare-root roses and container planters with reservoirs to boost wildlife while cutting upkeep.

articles.title: A moment that changed me: I nearly died when I was hit by a car – then started to relish life’s little luxuries
articles.trailText: For years, I kept a stash of ‘nice things’, waiting for the right occasion to use them. The accident taught me to live now, rather than in the future
articles.summary: A writer admits she kept luxury candles, balsamic and handwash 'for later' until last May in Bermuda, when an octogenarian driver hit her from behind, leaving her with broken bones, internal bruising and a concussion. Months of pain and recovery followed, during which she finally emptied her 'nice things' drawer. Daily rituals—lighting scented candles, using fancy olive oil, splashing premium handwash—rekindled her self-worth, strengthened bonds with loved ones and inspired her to relish life’s little luxuries in the moment.

articles.title: Vitamix 5200 review: it’s a legend for a reason
articles.trailText: The blender beloved by chefs and smoothie shops has all the power you need, and none of the frills you don’t
articles.summary: Vitamix’s 5200, its 2007 “legacy” model, remains a workhorse premium blender at $500. Powered by an 11.5-amp (2 HP) motor and laser-cut, angled stainless-steel blades, its 64 oz jug and included tamper effortlessly purees frozen fruit, seeds, soups, nut butters and pesto in under a minute. A simple speed dial and high/variable switch replace digital presets, while a 7-year warranty (extendable by 3) underlines durability and swift customer support. Easy to clean yet loud, the tall plastic jug raises microplastic and kitchen-space concerns—stainless-steel replacements are pricier. Despite minor drawbacks, the 5200’s unmatched power, reliability and manual control keep chefs and smoothie fans loyal.

articles.title: Running on empty: why are so many marathon runners so miserable?
articles.trailText: One in four endurance runners displays ‘worryingly high’ levels of anxiety and depression, according to a study led by a man who has himself run more than 400 marathons. Isn’t exercise supposed to make you feel good?
