articles.summary: Leo Lundy, himself a 400+ marathon veteran, led a survey revealing 25% of endurance runners suffer clinically significant anxiety and depression, despite 94% endorsing running's mental health benefits. While athletes chase runner’s high, many confront post-race emptiness, physical strain, and identity upheaval that can erode relationships—pejoratively termed “divorce by marathon.” Experts caution that obsessive training may shift into a coping tactic, recommending balanced recovery, enjoyment, and personal connections to protect wellbeing. Parallel Linnaeus University research notes post-race ambivalence, melancholy and energy loss, reinforcing calls for mental health support and balanced training.

articles.title: Late-night pub openings aren’t in the right spirit | Letters
articles.trailText: Letters: Readers respond to government plans for extending pub hours, highlighting the financial and health costs
articles.summary: Letters from readers critique the government’s proposal to extend pub licensing hours as a misguided growth strategy. Clive Turner argues late-night openings impose extra staffing costs while drink prices remain too high vs supermarkets, risking more closures. Emeritus Professor Alan Walker highlights the plan’s conflict with NHS goals, noting record alcohol-related deaths (10,473 in 2023) and £27.4bn annual harm cost, blaming drink industry influences. John Hall mocks the measure as an attempt to “drown sorrows” and distract citizens from looming ID cards and speech restrictions.

articles.title: My petty gripe: my coupled friends refuse to set me up with a potential mate. It’s not good enough
articles.trailText: We’ve had our fill of the apps, and the people who know us best aren’t pulling their weight. Couples, come on now!
articles.summary: The author, long disillusioned with dating apps, criticizes their coupled friends’ failure to play Cupid despite cultural expectations. Having been set up just once—awkwardly—she surveys fellow singles and finds widespread neglect: friends are too complacent to suggest dates. Pointing to a new boom in paid matchmakers and shared exhaustion with “hellscape” swiping, she implores partnered pals to activate their networks and arrange introductions. It may be awkward, she admits, but it beats wasted Tuesday swipes or two-hour “banter.” Families deserve the favor now, she argues, so singles can repay it when roles reverse.

articles.title: Houseplant clinic: my ‘cactus’ is getting too tall for my room
articles.trailText: It’s actually a euphorbia, and some careful pruning will solve your problem – and result in a more attractive plant
articles.summary: Your ‘cactus’ is actually Euphorbia trigona (African milk tree), a succulent that can outgrow indoor ceilings. To control height without harming the plant, top-prune its tallest stem using a clean, sharp blade and thick gloves to avoid irritating sap. After cutting, allow the wound to callus for several days; new shoots will emerge lower down, creating a bushier, sculptural form. You can root the removed tip in dry, gritty compost for a new plant. Maintain a bright, even-rotated position and schedule periodic trims as the only long-term indoor solution.

articles.title: My wife and I don’t have sex and she refuses to talk about it. Should I just give up?
articles.trailText: I long for physical intimacy and feel ashamed and unattractive when she rebuffs me – but she gets angry when I try to discuss it
articles.summary: After 10 years together (four married) and with young children, a woman describes a marriage devoid of sex: she always initiates rare encounters, her wife rebuffs her and neglects her pleasure, leaving her feeling unwanted and ashamed. Attempts to discuss intimacy outside couples therapy provoke avoidance or anger, and therapy has yet to address their sexual disconnect. Psychotherapist Pamela Stephenson Connolly recommends persistently raising sexuality in sessions, openly acknowledging her sense of loss and shame, and insisting on a supportive space to explore their sexual relationship and protect their marriage.

articles.title: The one change that worked: I swapped single-parent holiday hell for pet-sitting heaven
articles.trailText: Camping trips were miserable, and package holidays eye-wateringly expensive. Then my daughter and I discovered the joy of staying in strangers’ homes in return for a little dogwalking
articles.summary: After costly or unsuitable single-parent breaks—sticky tents, back-breaking bunks, overpriced resorts—writer and daughter discovered affordable, stress-free escapes via house-sitting. A £99-a-year membership secured tranquil sits in Devon and Dorset, culminating in a 10-day stay in Sussex caring for Buzz the labrador. Daily walks revealed hidden beaches; free time was spent browsing bookshops, kayak trips, manicures and debating BBC sitcom "Ghosts." Evenings by the fireplace deepened mother-daughter bonds. This trust-based home-and-pet care saved roughly £2,500 on comparable rentals, adding structure, authenticity and financial relief. She’s booked Surrey and hopes to sit abroad next year.

articles.title: Is it true that … cutting out carbs helps you lose weight?
articles.trailText: Weight loss is about consuming fewer calories than you burn, and reducing your intake of refined carbohydrates can play a part in that
articles.summary: Performance nutritionist Bethan Crouse at Loughborough University stresses that weight loss depends on an energy deficit. While she doesn’t recommend eliminating carbs entirely, modestly reducing refined carbohydrates—such as white bread and sweets—can help limit calories because protein, fibre and fats are more satiating. She suggests choosing brown rice, wholemeal bread and other high-fibre carbs at meals. On training days, increase carbohydrate intake to support exercise adaptation and immunity; on rest days, cut back while keeping protein, fruits, vegetables and healthy fats.

articles.title: A new start after 60: I realised I had autism – and suddenly my life made sense. I have never been so happy
articles.trailText: After decades of loneliness and depression, Cathleen Caffrey had come to think of herself as a bad person. Then she learned about others who had struggled to fit in …
articles.summary: Cathleen Caffrey, now 80 and sober for 42 years, spent decades battling depression, social isolation and self-blame over failed jobs and relationships. A family history of ADHD/autism and Covid-era research led her to self-identify as autistic, reframing lifelong shyness and career hurdles as neurodivergence rather than moral flaws. Living in a Santa Rosa senior mobile home park with her rescue dog, she now participates in philosophy groups and potlucks, and celebrated her 80th with 60 guests—more than she ever imagined. Embracing her diagnosis has brought her unexpected peace, purpose and happiness in later life.

articles.title: The kindness of strangers: a woman paid for my groceries when I couldn’t
articles.trailText: I was trying to move money over quickly but the banking app was down. Plus, I had a toddler and a baby with me, and one had started screaming
articles.summary: At an Aldi checkout, a harried mum with a toddler and screaming baby couldn’t complete her $100 grocery purchase after her banking app crashed. While the queue grew, a fellow customer stepped in, paid her bill and urged her to “pay it back in the community.” The relieved mother later honoured this by giving away baby items via a local group to a foster parent. Her unexpected kindness story highlights mutual support and the ripple effect of small acts in everyday life.

articles.title: What is the most common word in the world?
articles.trailText: The long-running series in which readers answer other readers’ questions on subjects ranging from trivial flights of fancy to profound scientific and philosophical concepts
articles.summary: In this edition of The Guardian’s long-running ‘Notes & Queries’ series — the weekly forum where readers submit and answer questions spanning trivial flights of fancy to deep scientific or philosophical concepts — reader Roland asks: beyond brand names and proper nouns, what is the world’s most common word, and how does its frequency differ across writing, speech and sign languages in various linguistic contexts? Contributors can cite corpus analyses, cross-linguistic data or personal experience, and submit answers or new questions below the article or to nq@theguardian.com. A selection of responses will appear next Sunday.

articles.title: Readers reply: Why do people become leftwing or rightwing?
articles.trailText: The long-running series in which readers answer other readers’ questions on subjects ranging from trivial flights of fancy to profound scientific and philosophical concepts
articles.summary: Guardian readers attribute left/right affiliation to a mix of personal, social and biological factors: economic hardship driving disaffection; opposition or inheritance of parents’ values; neurological traits (authoritarian predisposition, openness, strong disgust responses); search for belonging versus “othering” populism; community and tribal identity; cognitive habits shaped by education; emotional versus rational responses; and algorithmic polarisation. They conclude political identity emerges from complex nature–nurture interactions—temperament, upbringing, peer and media influence—and that fostering empathy, critical thinking and inclusion can counter extreme polarisation.

articles.title: Actor Eve Myles looks back: ‘Early on, I was told I wasn’t the typical leading lady. Now I realise my idiosyncrasies are what make me authentic’
articles.trailText: The Doctor Who and Torchwood star on growing up in a mining village, how Russell T Davies changed her life, the strain of playing tough characters – and sausage rolls
articles.summary: Welsh actor Eve Myles, born 1978 in Ystradgynlais, rose from BBC Wales’s Belonging (2000–09) to global fame as Gwen Cooper in Torchwood after Russell T Davies cast her in Doctor Who. Trained at the Royal Welsh College, she later headlined Keeping Faith/Un Bore Mercher and stars in ITV’s The Hack this autumn. Reflecting on childhood antics—swiping lipstick, drowning her third-birthday cake in icing and feasting on sausage rolls—she credits her mining-village upbringing and idiosyncrasies for her authenticity. Despite early industry remarks on her looks, she now embraces imperfections, tackles tough roles, balances family life with three daughters, and stays gratefully driven.

articles.title: Dining across the divide: ‘He was shocked when I told him that schools weaponise anxiety’
articles.trailText: They both dabble in knitting and disagree about the school system, but could they see eye-to-eye on AI?
articles.summary: Patrick, 31, PRU teacher and novice knitter who votes Labour (eyeing Lib Dem/Green), meets Molly, 50, NHS worker and Green-voter who knits socks, at a Japanese-Mexican fusion restaurant in London. They discuss the school system: Molly argues it ‘weaponises’ student anxiety based on her children’s struggles; Patrick contextualizes this as pressure from higher up but lauds his PRU’s empathetic, no-shout approach. On AI, Molly worries it undermines learning, while Patrick sees it as a tool to cut busywork and emphasize creativity and humanity in teaching. Patrick, Canadian-born, also condemns anti-migrant marches. They swap numbers, surprised to forge a genuine connection across generational and political divides.

articles.title: This is how we do it: ‘I worried about his kinks, but I’m learning to relax and be playful’
articles.trailText: Marty’s penchant for being demeaned and flogged was new to Viv, who had only slept with two other people when they met …
articles.summary: Marty, 47, emerged from a controlling marriage and an intense BDSM fling craving deep trust. With Viv, 43, who’d suffered vaginismus after 25 years of sexless marriage, he discovers gentle, affectionate sex and mutual generosity. Initially anxious about compatibility, they even bought a flogger but prioritize Viv’s comfort. Viv, once ashamed of sex, now feels aroused and playful, giggling through light humiliation. Together they practice open communication, boundary-respecting exploration and maintain separate homes to savor anticipation, learning that love can be soft, respectful and invigoratingly new.

articles.title: ‘I realised I’d been ChatGPT-ed into bed’: how ‘Chatfishing’ made finding love on dating apps even weirder
articles.trailText: Where once people were duped by soft-focus photos and borrowed chat-up lines, now they have to watch out for computer-generated charm. But it’s one thing to use a witty phrase – another thing entirely to build a whole fake persona …
articles.summary: By weaving AI-generated charm into dating app chats, some users – Rachel among them – have been “Chatfished,” growing intimate bonds online then meeting underwhelming real selves. While casual prompt-tweaking helps busy or insecure daters like Nick and Holly craft clearer, kinder messages, others outsource whole personas, risking misrepresentation and ghosting. Experts warn AI can facilitate icebreakers but not genuine chemistry; true connection demands in-person vulnerability, unfiltered conversation and mutual trust.

articles.title: I apologise too much, and it annoys everyone around me. How can I stop? | Ask Annalisa Barbieri
articles.trailText: Changing such ingrained habits isn’t easy, but when you’re about to apologise try counting to 10 or substituting a different phrase
articles.summary: An early-career academic in her late 30s with chronically low self-confidence finds herself apologising reflexively—jeopardising her teaching, public speaking and relationships despite ‘exposure therapy’ attempts. Psychotherapist Ali Ross traces the compulsion to childhood politeness that has morphed into self-sabotage and recommends a relational humanist approach. By focusing on self-compassion and ‘being’ rather than endless problem-solving, she can learn to pause before speaking, count to ten or replace “I’m sorry” with neutral phrases like “I see,” interrupting shame-driven reflexes and building genuine confidence.

articles.title: Cash gifts and no cake: how Australian couples spend and save on weddings
articles.trailText: With an average wedding cake costing $650 in 2025, more Australian couples are forgoing traditional weddings in favour of registry ceremonies, but others still spend big
articles.summary: Australian couples are increasingly opting for budget registry weddings—themed ceremonies at government offices from $397–$480—amid a 4.5% rise in average wedding costs to $35,315 in 2025. Between 2021 and 2024, NSW registry ceremonies jumped 87%, reaching 3,306 in 2024, while Victoria and Queensland report similar growth. Easy Weddings data shows 90% of couples now request cash gifts, families fund two-thirds of weddings, and average expenses include $15,987 for venues, $6,308 catering, $3,389 photography, and a $650 cake—many skipping dessert or ditching traditional cakes for alternatives. Sydney’s Liana and Tim budgeted $50K for a registry ceremony and 110-guest party, spending $47K.

articles.title: Going to the gym was too much effort, until I moved into one
articles.trailText: What would happen if you removed the obstacle of having to get to the gym? Brigid Delaney spends a week finding out
articles.summary: After years of skipping workouts because the gym felt too far and effortful, Brigid Delaney moved into Action Point, a four-storey gym-adjoined hotel in Phuket. Over seven days she woke at 7.20am for mobility classes, packed her schedule with cross-training, power yoga, Muay Thai, ice baths and saunas, and hit a 120g-protein diet. With massage, naps and nutrition seminars built in, she became stronger, more flexible and dependent on the gym’s frictionless routine, dreading the few moments outside the fitness bubble. Classes felt communal and inclusive, and many guests extended their stays, showing how embedding fitness and nutrition into daily life can permanently reshape habits.

articles.title: The moment I knew: he was so open and vulnerable, even as a bloke’s bloke
articles.trailText: Ameeta Patel was introduced to a seemingly alpha male called ‘Jungle Jim’. When he talked about his psychologist, she did a double take
articles.summary: At 40, divorced GP and mother of two Ameeta Patel moved to Alice Springs, where friends set her up with ‘Jungle Jim,’ an ex-Air Force father of four. Over a backyard barbecue, his tale of Kokoda Trail training and frank admission of seeing a psychologist post-separation revealed unexpected vulnerability beneath his alpha veneer. Bonding over expat origins, engineering fathers and family adventures, they blended their households. In 2011, amid a trip to the Taj Mahal, Jim surprised her with a sunset proposal, marrying their six children and proving love can spark in the midst of sticky date pudding and footy.

articles.title: ‘It’s like a scene from a movie’: Christian Barroso’s best phone picture
articles.trailText: On the 26th floor of a São Paulo skyscraper, the Brazilian photographer captured a stranger in a moment of solitude
articles.summary: Brazilian photographer Christian Barroso, who travelled from Rio de Janeiro after winning at the Mobile Photography Awards 2020, finally exhibited his work at São Paulo’s Farol Santander after a Covid delay until summer 2021. Visiting with three friends on a melancholic summer day, he paused at the 26th-floor café and, without speaking to her, shot a mid-20s woman enveloped in sunlight and long shadows. Drawing on William Eggleston’s influence, the frame’s geometric lines, deep shadows and vivid colours evoke a cinematic intimacy and contemplative solitude, mirroring Barroso’s own introspection.

articles.title: Who founded the Royal Ballet School in 1926? The Saturday quiz
articles.trailText: From Anne Boleyn’s ghost to a novel in three volumes, by a lady, test your knowledge with the Saturday quiz
articles.summary: Guardian’s Saturday quiz offers 15 general knowledge questions and answers spanning natural history, literature, sport, architecture, TV, film and thematic link puzzles. Highlights include Earth’s largest toothed predator (sperm whale), Jane Austen’s Sense and Sensibility, Deion Sanders’ dual Super Bowl and World Series feats, the founding of the Royal Ballet School by Ninette de Valois in 1926, Westminster Cathedral’s site, The Generation Game, black hole event horizons and Apocalypse Now’s iconic opening line. Plus puzzle rounds on film dynasties, record label founders, political office linkages and battle-named locales.

articles.title: Why do onions have layers and do sharks swim in groups? The kids’ quiz
articles.trailText: Five multiple-choice questions – set by children – to test your knowledge, and a chance to submit your own junior brainteasers for future quizzes
articles.summary: Hosted by Molly Oldfield, this kids’ quiz challenges you with five multiple-choice questions—from why onions form layers to whether sharks swim in groups. Crafted by children, it combines science and nature trivia, invites young readers to submit their own brainteasers, and spotlights Oldfield’s Everything Under the Sun podcast and related books for engaging, family-friendly learning.

articles.title: Blind date: ‘After too many tepid, app-based dates, outsourcing my love life to a paper is obviously the way to go’
articles.trailText: Hannah, 29, a horticulturist, meets Ioan, 28, a freelance consultant
articles.summary: Hannah, 29, a horticulturist, and Ioan, 28, a freelance consultant, meet at Emilia’s in London SW1 for a newspaper-arranged blind date. After initial awkwardness confirming identities, they share an animated conversation about dating apps, travel adventures and British TV icons. Both praise each other’s warmth, humor, energy and faultless manners. Hannah awards a 10/10, labels Ioan funny, charming and a gentleman; Ioan gives 8/10, calls Hannah assured, friendly and funny, and quips he’s saving a kiss for marriage. Both plan to meet again and would happily introduce one another to friends.

articles.title: Tim Dowling: I’m under an azure Croatian sky – fretting about the roof back home
articles.trailText: This should be a blissful break, but I’m distracted by the roofer’s messages relaying our house’s ongoing problems. My wife, meanwhile, remains firmly on holiday
articles.summary: Under a sunlit Croatian sky Tim Dowling lounges in a deckchair but is preoccupied by Michael the roofer’s video updates, revealing rotten plywood, an unventilated cold roof and persistent leaks. While his wife swims carefree, he frets over rising costs—scaffolding, revised quotes—and technical debates about soffits and ventilation. Architectural plans prove unhelpful, and scheduling video calls amid restaurant cancellations adds to the chaos. Michael warns that without proper exit vents, condensation issues may persist, turning a blissful break into a home-repair nightmare.

articles.title: Soil in need of some love? Sow green manure in your garden and you’ll reap the benefits
articles.trailText: Plants like lupins, ryegrass and field beans can help fix nitrogen in the soil, suppress weeds and increase biodiversity
articles.summary: After returning from holiday to an overgrown, weedy plot, a six-months-pregnant gardener enlists help to clear pernicious intruders and prepare beds for green manure. Sown now for overwintering, forage rye, Italian ryegrass, vetch and field beans cover the soil, suppress weeds, boost pollinator biodiversity and fix nitrogen, while lupins and bird’s-foot trefoil add flowers. Once mature, these crops can be dug in, composted or left as mulch to enrich clay and heavy soils ahead of spring planting.

articles.title: Ty Bouncers and food toys tipped to be must-have Christmas presents
articles.trailText: Soft-toy collecting back in vogue for children and adults, says Hamleys
articles.summary: Expert buyers at Hamleys predict Ty Bouncers—a £7 fuzzy, face-emblazoned ball in 80 character designs—will top Christmas lists alongside tactile food-themed plush like a £12 pizza slice. Hamleys’ ‘Festive 15’ blends low-tech simplicity (Heritage teddy bears, wooden stackers) with tech items: an £80 Robosen Woody robot, a remote-control drift car, AI-powered Soccer Dash, and a £40 Star Wars Power Crystal Lightsaber. Buoyed by an 8% UK toy-sales rebound driven by film tie-ins, manga/anime merch and ‘newstalgia’ revivals, Hamleys spots a cultural shift to uncomplicated, sensory play for children and adult collectors.

articles.title: Experience: I own the world’s largest Monopoly collection
articles.trailText: Every set is exciting. I’ve currently got 4,379 different ones. The dream is to hit 4,500, maybe even 5,000
articles.summary: In a 25-year quest, a DHL employee has amassed 4,379 unique Monopoly sets, setting four Guinness World Records. He bought his first classic edition aged 30 and has spent £400,000 building his seal-only collection—rare variants like a silver London edition, Park Hyatt Sydney hotel set, Twycross Zoo, 90th-anniversary US edition—housed in a Middlesex warehouse. Collecting sparks global connections, TV and radio appearances, and he plans to reach 4,500–5,000 sets by Monopoly’s 100th anniversary in 2035.

articles.title: My brother and sister are angry at my parents. I feel caught in the middle. What can I do? | Leading quesstions
articles.trailText: To avoid becoming a conflict manager, you might want to pick phrases to repeat like a broken record, writes advice columnist Eleanor Gordon-Smith. They might stop trying to involve you
articles.summary: An advice column on feeling caught between siblings who accuse their parents of neglect and manipulation and parents trying to make amends. Gordon-Smith explains that each side is telling their subjective truth—what happened versus how it’s weighed morally, past versus present behaviour—and recommends avoiding taking sides by repeatedly using set phrases: to siblings, “I’m not asking you to forgive them, I just feel differently”; to parents, “I love you but I won’t be your mediator.” By becoming a conversational dead-end, you maintain relationships and resist being a conflict manager.

articles.title: These glasses make economy class bearable with a virtual 147-inch screen
articles.trailText: If you have to be stuck on a plane without any space to spare, you can at least bring your own personal movie theater
articles.summary: Tech writer praises XReal One AR glasses ($499) for turning cramped economy seats into a personal theater and mobile workstation. The USB-C headset creates a persistent virtual display (up to 147″) that mirrors or extends your laptop, eliminating tray-table limitations and reducing cabin light disturbance. Pair with the XReal Beam Pro ($199) to run a dual-app Android interface without a laptop, and add a folding Protoarc Bluetooth keyboard or Samsung Dex on a compatible Galaxy phone for full typing. Downsides include extra power drain, occasional eye strain when switching views, but overall a game-changer for in-flight productivity.

articles.title: I’m sensitive to the scents my children’s friend brings into the house. What do I do?
articles.trailText: You can set boundaries for your health in our perfume-obsessed world – but you should be extra considerate
articles.summary: A 47-year-old parent has developed sensitivity to perfumes and fabric softeners, making a neighborhood boy’s heavily scented play dates unbearable indoors. With fragrance sales exploding—$85.6 bn so far in 2025—and one-third of people reporting adverse reactions, the columnist advises first talking with the child’s parents. Frame it as a health need (“I get sick from strong scents”) rather than a judgment on their laundry. Offer outdoor or park play dates, and explain the rule to kids as akin to a peanut allergy in the nose. This preserves friendships and sets considerate boundaries.

articles.title: Simple menu, minimal stress, banging playlist: top chefs’ tips for a dinner party even the host will enjoy
articles.trailText: Love to feed your friends but hate spending a fortune and working yourself to exhaustion? Here’s how the experts ramp up the flavour while dialling down the chaos
articles.summary: Multiple top chefs share low-stress dinner party methods: focus on simple, well-practised crowd-pleasers; build a versatile base dish (vegan dal or stew) then optional protein or sides for dietary needs; plan meticulously—menus, ingredient lists, cooking schedule—and favor dishes that work at room temp or can be prepped early. Stock pantry staples (bread crumbs, dressings, frozen fruit, cod roe) and seasonal ingredients to cut costs. Test recipes ahead, adapt complexity to group size (one bulk dish for 6+, more courses for smaller). Enlist guests to help, curate seating and playlist for ambiance, and keep easy show-stopping starters, mains and make-ahead puddings on hand.

articles.title: Thursday news quiz: book bans, bonkbuster authors and a papal visit
articles.trailText: Test yourself on topical news trivia, pop culture and general knowledge every Thursday. How will you fare?
articles.summary: Our weekly Thursday News Quiz No 218 tests your recall of recent headlines—from debates over book bans and the revival of bonkbuster authors to the Pope’s upcoming visit—alongside pop-culture and general-knowledge challenges. Tackle topical trivia sprinkled with in-jokes, then post your score in the comments or submit evidence-backed complaints about any errors. As a cheeky aside, the quiz suggests you could instead watch the short film Honey, Do You See Me? by EERA.

articles.title: You be the judge: should my boyfriend get rid of his laundry basket?
articles.trailText: Anita thinks dirty clothes can go straight in the machine. Jayden believes the laundry hamper serves a purpose. Who’s the basket case? You decide
articles.summary: Anita and Jayden clash over a bulky wicker laundry basket in their new flat. Anita deems it ugly, unhygienic and space-wasting, insisting dirty clothes go straight into the washer to prevent odours and clutter. Jayden argues hidden laundry in a wardrobe is musty, the basket helps build full, energy-efficient loads and carries sentimental value. Guardian readers largely side with a compromise: swap in a smaller, discreet hamper and agree on more regular washes to balance aesthetics, hygiene and practicality.

articles.title: The armed robber who went straight: John McAvoy was born into the criminal life. Here’s how he escaped it
articles.trailText: His stepfather was a serious criminal. His uncle was one of the Brink’s-Mat heist gang. McAvoy followed them into crime – and into prison. Then one day in the gym he discovered the talent, drive, support and friendship that changed everything …
articles.summary: John McAvoy, born into a criminal family, followed his stepfather and uncle into armed robbery, serving nearly a decade in high-security prisons. In solitary and in Belmarsh’s notorious HSU, he discovered rowing in the gym, channeling his drive into endurance training. Supported by officer Darren Davis, he broke indoor rowing world records behind bars and qualified as a personal trainer. Paroled in 2012, McAvoy pursued triathlons, Ironman races and ultra-marathons, earning Nike sponsorship and campaigning for prison reform. He founded the Alpine Run Project, guiding underprivileged youth through a six-month fitness programme culminating in the Ultra-Trail du Mont-Blanc. McAvoy’s journey illustrates transformation through sport, mentorship and resilience.

articles.title: Look out for number one! Selfish self-help books are booming – but will they improve your life?
articles.trailText: If you yearn for an Ayn Randian existence of absolute self-reliance, there are plenty of bestsellers that can help. They may not make you happier though
articles.summary: In recent years UK self-help sales soared, especially books urging radical self-prioritization: Ingrid Clayton’s Fawning labels people-pleasing as trauma response; Mel Robbins’s Let Them Theory champions “let me, let them”; Mark Manson’s The Subtle Art of Not Giving a F*ck dismisses others’ opinions; Kishimi and Koga’s The Courage to Be Disliked applies Adler’s teleology; Joseph Nguyen’s Don’t Believe Everything You Think prescribes stopping thought. Despite their Randian appeal, Yale’s Laurie Santos warns research shows true wellbeing comes from social connection and giving to others, not self-focus.

articles.title: Can’t sleep? Turn on, tune in and drop off | Letters
articles.trailText: Letters: Gillian Greenfield on coping with maintenance insomnia and Michael Peel on our changing sleeping habits
articles.summary: Letters in the Guardian: Gillian Greenfield of Haydon Bridge describes how tuning into on-demand radio shows stopped her maintenance insomnia by occupying her mind, letting her drift off without anxiety and catching up on podcasts she can’t listen to by day. Michael Peel of London points to pre-industrial ‘split sleep’ patterns—young adults taking a ‘middle watch’—arguing modern sleepers should honour natural biorhythms instead of resisting them. Both letters suggest alternative strategies to combat nighttime wakefulness by leveraging distraction or aligning with historic sleep cycles.

articles.title: Typewriter reveals unexpected genius | Brief letters
articles.trailText: Brief letters: Guaranteed immortality | Living with rejection | Going like hot cakes | Poetry in lotion | The failure of IA
articles.summary: Letters to the Guardian’s Brief letters column on 8 October commend inventor-novelist Bob Brody for his self-feeding typewriter that converts shredded paper into fresh A4 sheets, guaranteeing his creative legacy (Noel Chidwick, Edinburgh); Lindsay Camp in Bristol reflects on rejection and authenticity; Margaret Clarke (Australia) recalls a family quip about ‘stale sponge’ on a TV cookery show; Joanna Rimmer (Newcastle) endorses ‘motion is lotion’ for joint health; Barry Coomber (Pinner) criticizes a ‘Britian’ typo on Tory conference chocolates as an information architecture lapse. Readers are invited to share opinions for possible publication.

articles.title: ‘I carved until my fingers bled’: inside the baffling world of pumpkin obsessives
articles.trailText: Fans of the orange vegetable are flocking to farms to pick their own, commissioning intricate lanterns and even dressing their kids up as the gourd. How did the humble pumpkin become October’s overlord?
articles.summary: Across the UK, pumpkins have morphed from modest autumn crops into Instagram-friendly icons and a booming festival circuit. At Farmer Copley’s Pontefract farm, 300,000 gourds of 50 varieties anchor vintage fairground rides, street food and family photo-ops; crowds dress in themed knits, queue for carved lantern displays and toast s’mores beneath “Hello Pumpkin” arches. Retailers from Sainsbury’s to B&M stock mugs, soaps and spice-infused drinks as the pumpkin-spice craze blossoms. Carving pros like Jamie Jones spend 20 hours sculpting bespoke gourds for £300-£1,500. After Halloween, unsold pumpkins are ploughed back, closing the cycle of this global gourd takeover.

articles.title: A moment that changed me: I stopped restraining myself – and found the love of my life
articles.trailText: For years I tried to be the perfect girlfriend: bright, funny, engaging and fragrant. Then I stubbed my toe, and my ferocious roar of pain showed me I could be myself
articles.summary: In her mid-20s the author spent years meticulously managing her image—bright, funny, fragrant and emotionally restrained—to win male approval. When friend-turned-partner Luke, a newspaper colleague who saw her hungover and in gym kit, started driving her to work, their bond deepened naturally. Two months into dating, she stubbed her toe and unleashed an unfiltered roar of pain. Luke’s calm concern in that unguarded moment showed her she could drop the ‘perfect girlfriend’ act. Embracing vulnerability transformed their relationship: they got engaged three years later and have been married nearly 15 years.

articles.title: ‘Stay true to yourself – and fly closer to the sun’: what I’ve learned from 50 years of rejection
articles.trailText: As a writer, I have been rejected thousands of times, and it initially led to shock, denial and anger. Then I accepted it. Here’s what you can gain from doing so too
articles.summary: Bob Brody, a consultant and longtime essayist, recounts 50 years and thousands of writing rejections—from novels to op-eds—progressing through shock, anger and bargaining to a seventh stage: acceptance. He argues rejection can expose misaligned ideas, prompt valuable revisions, and build humility and resilience. Citing literary giants and public figures who overcame dozens of no’s, he distills five lessons: scrutinize and rework each rejected pitch; write authentically and with purpose; keep multiple projects in development; persist despite setbacks; and maintain faith in your own judgment. Ultimately, he urges embracing “no” as the key step toward achieving “yes.”

articles.title: I would like a relationship – but I have a constant craving for casual sex
articles.trailText: I long to settle down with someone who can fulfill my sexual and emotional needs. But every time the excitement of a new relationship subsides, I want to stray
articles.summary: A late-40s gay man who’s enjoyed mostly casual sex since age 19 struggled in a four-year relationship that left him emotionally and sexually unfulfilled. He still craves novelty and feels unable to sustain monogamy but worries open arrangements breed jealousy. Pamela Stephenson Connolly advises his desires and capacity for intimacy may shift over time, urging him to focus on present connections without anxiety about future labels. By appreciating each partner and observing when he truly seeks deeper commitment, he’ll discover whether to pursue a stable relationship or embrace casual freedom.

articles.title: How do you talk to kids about violence in the news? We asked experts
articles.trailText: The Guardian spoke with therapists, media experts and journalists about helping kids process bad news and develop healthy media habits
articles.summary: The Guardian spoke with seven experts—including psychiatrist Eugene Beresin, psychologist Tori Cordiano and media professor Tara Conley—on guiding children through violent or disturbing news. They recommend first asking what children have heard, then providing clear facts and emotional validation: Are you safe? Who’s protecting you? Encourage questions, model balanced news consumption, set media boundaries (time limits, no devices in bedrooms) and develop family media plans. Teach critical media literacy—fact-checking via reputable outlets—reinforce democratic norms, avoid background news noise and share supportive rituals like letter-writing or volunteering to bolster coping skills.

articles.title: Houseplant clinic: why is there a chalky crust on my plant’s soil?
articles.trailText: It’s a buildup of mineral salts from hard tap water or fertiliser. Switching to rainwater or filtered water, and feeding only in spring and summer, will help
articles.summary: Chalky white crust on spider-plant soil stems from mineral salt buildup from hard tap water or fertiliser. As water evaporates, salts concentrate at the surface and roots, scorching leaf tips and altering pH. Remedy by flushing with tepid water until runoff runs clear, repeat in a week; if crust persists repot in fresh, free-draining, peat-free compost and clean the pot. Trim brown tip tissue. Prevent by using rain/filtered/cooled water, fertilising only in spring and summer, flushing containers monthly, watering deeply but infrequently and emptying saucers.

articles.title: ‘Fiery and spectacular’ rainbow of autumn colour set to bloom across UK
articles.trailText: National Trust gardeners expect vivid hues and bountiful fungi, nuts and berries thanks to recent weather conditions
articles.summary: National Trust horticulturists, led by John Deakin, forecast an unusually vivid autumn colourwave across UK gardens after a sun-drenched summer and wet September. Warm days and plentiful rain have triggered a second flush in annuals and herbaceous perennials and a mast year of acorns, conkers, hedgerow fruit, mushrooms and berries. Sites from Sheffield Park and Petworth to Stourhead, Dyffryn and Dunham Massey are primed for fiery reds, golden yellows and rare purples, with upcoming cold nights and frosts set to intensify the display into late October and early November.

articles.title: You can’t just press ‘undo’ on your life. To move forward, you must first feel your grief and rage
articles.trailText: Many of us try to reframe our disappointments, to put a happy face on sad circumstances. But the path to growth is paved with difficult emotions, and we have to experience them honestly
articles.summary: Psychotherapist Moya Sarner reflects on how everyday disappointments—from a cancelled summer holiday for her husband’s surgery to the relentless demands of newborn care—reveal our impulse to ‘undo’ pain by rushing to positivity. Instead, she shows that honest grieving—allowing anger, sadness and frustration—shared with loved ones or offered to a distressed infant, fosters emotional growth. Rejecting false reframing and numbing defenses, she argues, enables authentic change by cultivating the capacity to feel and process all difficult emotions.

articles.title: The one change that worked: I was lost in the infinite scroll – until a small ritual renewed my love of reading
articles.trailText: My ability to concentrate diminished as I spent more time on my phone. So I started to log and learn every new word I came across, and felt my brain begin to flex
articles.summary: After endless scrolling eroded her focus, the author vowed to log every unfamiliar word—across novels, articles and overheard speech—into a simple phone doc and revisit it weekly. This micro-ritual, while slowing her reading and often impractical on the Tube, became a mental workout and informal journal of her literary journey. Deploying only a handful of entries in daily conversation, she nonetheless rekindled precise language use, sharpened her attention and rediscovered the pleasure of slow, immersive reading.

articles.title: Is it true that … you get shorter as you get older?
articles.trailText: Some loss of height is inevitable, but diet, exercise and a healthy lifestyle can help slow the decline in bone and muscle mass as we age
articles.summary: Professor Adam Taylor explains that from age 40 humans lose around 1 cm per decade (0.08–0.1% per year for men, 0.12–0.14% for women), driven by spinal disc dehydration, bone density decline and muscle loss, exacerbated by slumped posture. Height plateaus at 30–35 before gradual shrinkage as vertebral discs lose water and cancellous bone condenses. Men and women also stoop to shift their center of gravity. While unavoidable, a calcium/Vitamin D–rich diet, weight-bearing exercise, posture correction and early avoidance of tobacco and alcohol can slow bone and muscle decline and reduce chronic risks like osteoporosis, osteoarthritis and heart failure.

articles.title: ‘Messiness makes you different’: Lukas Gage on meds, trauma, memoir – and filming TV’s most sexually frank scene
articles.trailText: The White Lotus and Euphoria star has written a ‘premature celebrity memoir’ that takes in abuse, family dysfunction, personality disorders, shame and heartbreak. He explains why now was the right time to write it
articles.summary: Actor Lukas Gage (White Lotus, Euphoria) has published I Wrote This Book for Attention, a raw “premature celebrity memoir” chronicling his turbulent upbringing—early validation-seeking, father’s abandonment, mother’s gambling, brother’s heroin addiction—and a molestation at summer camp. He recounts chaotic romances (including a brief marriage to stylist Chris Appleton), his path to queerness, borderline personality disorder diagnosis and trial of meds. Gage also describes pitching TV’s most explicit sex scene, navigating viral audition fallout, and the peaks and troughs of fame. Without neat resolutions, the book celebrates “messiness” as fuel for creativity and authenticity.

articles.title: The kindness of strangers: my melons went flying and a group of old ladies came to the rescue
articles.trailText: White hair, head scarves and one with a walking stick – they looked like they had stepped out of the same babushka doll
articles.summary: Accompanying her mum on a weekly fruit-and-veg run, the author offered to wheel a small red trolley packed with groceries and a box of honeydew melons across a busy intersection. When the trolley snagged on a traffic island, the melons flew in six directions. Out stepped a fearless quartet of elderly women – white-haired, head-scarved, one with a walking stick – who halted oncoming cars, gathered every runaway melon and restored them to the box. Though she never ate the honeydew, the author cherishes their silent kindness.

articles.title: The truth about vitamin pills: should midlife women start taking supplements – and if so, which ones?
articles.trailText: The market for supplements is booming and it can be difficult to know which are actually any use. Dietitians give the lowdown on those you should take and those you can ditch
articles.summary: As women enter midlife, absorption of nutrients like B12 and calcium declines due to ageing and hormonal changes, increasing bone, cardiovascular and muscle-health risks. Experts urge optimizing diet—adequate protein, fibre, oily fish, dairy or fortified milks—before adding targeted supplements: vitamin D3 (≥10 mcg), omega-3 (EPA/DHA), magnesium, calcium, B12 and iron if heavy bleeding. Trial each supplement alone for 4–12 weeks, test to confirm deficiencies, choose third-party verified brands, and avoid mega-doses or ambiguous “food-grown”/“micronised” claims. Consult a dietitian or pharmacist to tailor regimen, monitor interactions (e.g., PPIs, metformin) and prioritize lifestyle foundations over quick fixes.

articles.title: Broadcaster Anthea Turner looks back: ‘I spent my Blue Peter era scared to death I was going to get found out’
articles.trailText: The presenter on building Thunderbirds’ Tracy Island, being in the tabloids and getting out of her comfort zone
articles.summary: Anthea Turner, born 1960 in Stoke-on-Trent, is reflecting on her Blue Peter era (1992–94), where despite live craft demos like building Tracy Island for 8 million viewers, she feared being “found out” due to dyslexia and later weathered tabloid scrutiny gracefully. Her meticulous preparation fueled a versatile career spanning GMTV, reality shows (Celebrity Big Brother, Dancing on Ice, Celebrity SAS), TV, radio, publishing and lifestyle ventures. Now partnering with Corgi for Thunderbirds’ 60th anniversary, she embraces aging, social media positivity and challenges like trekking Kilimanjaro.

articles.title: Dining across the divide: ‘It actually scares me that potential Reform voters are not all tub-thumping thugs’
articles.trailText: Can a retired lecturer and an economics tutor agree on immigration, the NHS or whether the UK should introduce a wealth tax?
articles.summary: Economics tutor Yusuf (47, Edgbaston, centre-left, ex-Labour voter) and retired nurse-lecturer Mark (66, Walsall, ex-Conservative, considering Reform) share steak and ice cream at Gaucho in Birmingham. They swap views on small-boat immigration—Yusuf urging empathy, Mark citing capacity and integration concerns—yet find common ground on wealth tax and Thatcher’s inequalities. Mark worries about NHS privatisation under Reform; Yusuf is surprised moderate Reform supporters aren’t “union-jack thugs.” Their calm, stereotype-busting dialogue illustrates how cross-party conversations can shift perspectives.

articles.title: I was 31, burned out, and single. Would a string of dates with French men bring back my joie de vivre?
articles.trailText: I was working 80-hour weeks and having no luck on the New York singles scene. A move to Europe opened my mind – and helped me find love in the most unexpected place
articles.summary: Burned out after 80-hour weeks and stalled New York dating at age 31, a US editor quits her job to spend three months in France—Grenoble, Nice, Paris—to relearn French, see art, hike the Alps and Mediterranean, and date freely. Over a series of encounters with attentive French partners Thomas and Gaëtan, she rediscovers romance, cultural civility and joie de vivre. Ultimately she returns home fluent in French, having finished her novel, but finds lasting love by marrying her ex David, who had waited for her.

articles.title: This is how we do it: ‘Asexuality is a spectrum. I don’t experience sexual desire (but I do like having orgasms)’
articles.trailText: Embracing Sarah’s asexuality has allowed her and Cameron to connect in many different ways
articles.summary: Sarah, 37, realized in 2021 she’s asexual—no sexual desire despite enjoying orgasms—after feeling ‘broken’ about sex. She and partner Cameron, 36, navigated differing libidos via an open arrangement and honest communication. Sarah now chooses sex to feel intimacy; Cameron reframed attraction as emotional connection through shared activities like adult Lego, mocktails, cooking and walks. Embracing asexuality expanded their toolkit for romance: sex becomes intentional bonding, jealousy eased, and they creatively sustain closeness, demonstrating that sexuality is a spectrum and intimacy transcends desire.

articles.title: I am three months sober. How do I support my 11-year-old autistic son? | Ask Annalisa Barbieri
articles.trailText: Your son’s autism may make it even harder to navigate this situation. Try to show him things are better, rather than just telling him
articles.summary: A recovering alcoholic mother, three months sober after two years of daily heavy drinking, seeks to rebuild trust with her 11-year-old autistic son, who became hyper-vigilant and controlling, believing he had to stop her. After living with his father, he’s back in her care as she engages children’s services and substance-abuse support. Therapist Rebecca Harris advises showing consistent change over promises, establishing routines, using side-by-side or preferred communication channels, acknowledging his safe space with Dad, and setting clear boundaries. Recommended resources include Al-Anon/Alateen, Nacoa and the National Autistic Society to support both parent and child.

articles.title: The moment I knew: as the countdown reached one, something instinctive pulled us together
articles.trailText: At an eclectic performance, contemporary dancer James Welsby was instantly taken with Jarred. A midnight kiss confirmed a deeper connection
articles.summary: Contemporary dancer and drag queen James Welsby met circus arts student Jarred Dewey at a 2009 Melbourne fringe festival’s nude performance party. They bonded over movement, Facebook chats, Xena: Warrior Princess and horror films, and by New Year’s Eve shared an instinctive kiss on a Carlton North balcony that launched their long-distance romance—he touring with Circa, Welsby on the road with his shows. After Jarred’s 2019 bicep surgery brought them back to Australia, they moved in during Covid lockdown, exchanged playful dual proposals in Brunswick Heads and invested in a home rather than a wedding.

articles.title: ‘I have no doubt this cat could take him down!’: Dorothy O’Donnell’s best phone picture
articles.trailText: The San Francisco photographer on a spontaneous moment that turned into a cute photo
articles.summary: San Francisco street photographer Dorothy O’Donnell captures a spontaneous moment on her phone: the ears of her chihuahua mix Lucky, perked at a rival neighborhood cat through a window atop North Beach’s iconic slanted sidewalk. Using Lightroom for minor tweaks, she frames just the back of Lucky’s head and distinctive ears to emphasize the playful tension and narrative. O’Donnell’s early morning routine—coffee and dog walk—paired with North Beach’s colorful characters and Victorian architecture, turns everyday scenes into charming, story-driven images that she hopes will make viewers smile.

articles.title: Is whale blubber what makes bubble gum stretchy? The kids’ quiz
articles.trailText: Five multiple-choice questions – set by children – to test your knowledge, and a chance to submit your own junior brainteasers for future quizzes
articles.summary: The Guardian’s life & style section presents a five-question kids’ quiz curated by children, tackling curiosities like if whale blubber gives bubble gum its stretch. Hosted by Molly Oldfield (Everything Under the Sun podcast and related books including the Quiz Book and All Around the World), the quiz blends myth-busting and science in multiple-choice format. Young participants test their knowledge and are encouraged to contribute their own junior brainteasers for upcoming quizzes, fostering curiosity and engagement.

articles.title: Explorer Dwayne Fields replaced Bear Grylls in what role? The Saturday quiz
articles.trailText: From a Margaret Atwood trilogy and Abba’s fourth UK hit to Benny Hill and Rishi Sunak, test your knowledge with the Saturday quiz
articles.summary: The Guardian’s Saturday Quiz comprises 15 questions: eight fact-based items—such as naming the Eiffel Tower as the 1889 Exposition Universelle’s enduring legacy; Netflix’s ‘K-pop Demon Hunters’ for girl group Huntr/x; the 1992 Conservatives’ 14m-vote record; Dwayne Fields replacing Bear Grylls as UK chief scout; Earth’s core metals (iron, nickel); the sword-billed hummingbird’s beak; Women’s Super League side London City Lionesses; and the £90k VAT threshold—followed by seven connection puzzles linking palindromic titles (MaddAddam, SOS, Tenet), betting-odds slang (evens, 2–8/1), Antarctic seal species, Southampton-born personalities, Dresden architecture highlights, Maslow’s hierarchy of needs, and Henry VIII’s wives’ burial sites.

articles.title: Blind date: ‘As she was trying to show me something on her phone, there was a guy’s fully nude video on there’
articles.trailText: Jenny, 31, a lash technician, meets Nova, 27, a master’s student
articles.summary: Jenny, 31 lash technician, meets Nova, 27 master’s student, at Fremantle Bar & Kitchen, London E16. Both hope for good vibes: first impressions hit ease despite Jenny’s initial ‘rude boy’ flash and Nova’s lateness. Conversation flowed, no awkward pauses, immaculate manners, hilarious dog impression; they traded accent imitations and lighthearted banter, sharing a cheeky kiss. Nova admires Jenny’s drink capacity and arm-wrestle victory, while a surprise nude video gaffe on her phone provided comic relief. Both rate the night 9/10 and plan a second date.

articles.title: Tim Dowling: I love books – but can’t remember anything about the ones I’ve just read
articles.trailText: In bed I lie awake, staring at the books on my nightstand, trying to remember a single salient fact about any of them
articles.summary: Guardian columnist Tim Dowling recounts his distress at loving books but retaining no details once he closes them. After his son unexpectedly asks for a recommendation, he suggests a “blue” translation and Death Comes for the Archbishop, only to discover he remembers nothing of either. Toward night, he lies awake over an empty recall, convinced his accumulated literary wisdom has vanished. Humorous family exchanges—his wife’s shrug, cryptic texts—and an airport chat among retirees underscore his poignant, comic anxiety about memory and age.

articles.title: Tell us: how did you end a dry spell in your relationship?
articles.trailText: We would like to hear your advice for ending a dry spell in a romantic relationship
articles.summary: Life & Style invites readers to submit personal anecdotes on how they broke out of a sexual dry spell—highlighting tips from unusual aphrodisiacs and routine shake-ups to new communication styles. Contributors must secure all parties’ consent, agree to share personal details under the Guardian’s Terms of Service and Privacy Policy, and can access support via a help link if they encounter form issues. Entries will inform a feature on reigniting intimacy. The Guardian will compile these experiences into a practical guide for couples seeking to refresh their romantic lives.

articles.title: Layne Beachley: ‘My peers tagged me as having the compassion of a tiger shark’
articles.trailText: The seven-time world surfing champion talks about her search for self-worth, being adopted and hearing the wake-up call to live a better life
articles.summary: Seven-time world surfing champion Layne Beachley prioritises daily surf sessions at Freshwater to ‘decompress’ but has learned to balance her relentless drive—once labelled as having ‘the compassion of a tiger shark’—with self-care. After discovering she was adopted at eight, she chased world titles to earn self-worth, sacrificing her body and mind until a spine injury and her husband’s wake-up call prompted healing. Now a motivational speaker, co-founder of Awake Academy and host of The Wake-Up Call podcast, she empowers others and champions women surfers.

articles.title: ‘Deadly but unforgettable’: conversation pits make a comeback on and off screen
articles.trailText: Sunken lounges were a popular feature in mid-century homes. Now the ‘nest-like’ spaces are featuring in science fiction and offering a solution to tech-reliant living
articles.summary: Mid-century sunken ‘conversation pits’ are resurging onscreen (Fantastic Four, Alien: Earth) and in real homes, driven by nostalgia and a craving for deeper, tech-free social spaces within curved, maximalist designs. Yelp reports mid-century furniture searches up 319%, curved features up 124%. Architects in Sydney and Melbourne note client requests for circular or banquette pits to foster intimacy in open-plan layouts. While stylish, pits pose trip hazards, costly floor-level work and risk dating interiors. Cushions, throws, shoe-free, screen-free zones or pit-like furniture offer safer, scalable solutions.

articles.title: Feeling out of place? How to beat impostor syndrome
articles.trailText: Do you struggle to take a compliment? Cringe at your own achievements? From celebrating your wins to embracing your failures, these top tips will help you banish self-doubt
articles.summary: Psychologists say up to 82% of people experience impostor syndrome—persistent self-doubt despite achievements—in work, relationships and social media. Experts recommend writing down worst-case predictions and tracking outcomes, embracing uncertainty by acknowledging what you don’t know, daily logging three wins, compiling a sprawling achievement CV, learning to accept compliments, and reframing failures as growth. Identify your transferable “secret sauce” to connect past successes to new contexts. Finally, share insecurities with trusted peers to normalize doubts but avoid romanticizing imposter feelings that ultimately hold you back.

articles.title: Harvest festival is an ideal time to reflect before preparing the garden for winter
articles.trailText: This ancient tradition involves offering gratitude for the growing season – and the abundance we may take for granted while many go without
articles.summary: Harvest festival, timed to the harvest moon near the autumn equinox, is an ancient agrarian tradition of offering gratitude at the close of the growing season. Historically, rural communities wove corn dollies—figures from the final sheaf believed to carry the harvest spirit through winter—before ploughing them back into fields for spring fertility. Reflecting on yields, acknowledging climate impacts on plants and the hidden labor behind abundance, this moment invites gardeners to pause. With the 7 October harvest moon approaching, the article suggests carving out personal rituals—like a cold sea swim—before winter garden prep begins.

articles.title: Experience: I put on the world’s first deaf rave for deaf ravers like me
articles.trailText: Finding a venue was a headache. Some bookers thought it was a joke
articles.summary: Hackney-born twin rendered deaf at birth, DJ Chinaman (fluent in BSL, lip-reading) loved raves but rarely met fellow deaf attendees and was once barred by a bouncer. In May 2003 they launched Deaf Rave at International Students House, adapting heavy basslines for tactile experience, adding deaf dancers and MC Geezer signing bars. 700 tickets sold, sparking community bonds, friendships, marriages. Deaf Rave grew into major festival stages (Glastonbury, Boomtown), Fabric’s vibrating floor, haptic vests, Shanghai exchange. Awarded honorary MA and MBE, they now teach DJ workshops to deaf kids and host family festivals, amplifying deaf culture and unity.

articles.title: I have a crippling fear of being judged. How can I overcome this? | Leading questions
articles.trailText: Is it worth paying with your life to avoid being mocked, asks advice columnist Eleanor Gordon-Smith. Practice valuing your own judgments as much as other people’s
articles.summary: An advice column addresses a writer’s crippling fear of being judged—rooted in a childhood of mockery—that sabotages their personal life despite confidence at work. Eleanor Gordon-Smith suggests cognitive reframing: recognize most people aren’t watching, remind yourself of proven competence, and accept that any mockery wouldn’t matter more than your own self-assessment. She warns that avoiding mockery at the cost of freedom is too high a price and recommends therapy to align actions with values and extend the unburdened confidence you enjoy at work into your personal life.

articles.title: Tell us about your bad first date experiences
articles.trailText: We would like to hear from people about their first date horror stories and what went wrong
articles.summary: The Guardian invites readers to share their worst first-date horror stories—from dates who dominated conversation with ex-talk to those whose profile pictures bore no resemblance. The call-out asks: what went wrong, did you leave early or stay until the end, and did the experience change your approach to dating or feel like mere bad luck? Contributors can submit via an online form (with troubleshooting help available) and are reminded to review the terms of service and privacy policy before sending their anecdotes.

articles.title: Thursday news quiz: AI actors, gorgeous trees and moons with signs of life
articles.trailText: Test yourself on topical news trivia, pop culture and general knowledge every Thursday. How will you fare?
articles.summary: The Guardian’s Thursday Quiz No 217 challenges readers on current affairs, pop culture and general knowledge with questions spanning AI actors, breathtaking tree discoveries and potential signs of life on moons. This edition also debuts a specialist celebrity trivia round alongside the usual mix of topical news stories. There are no prizes—just a weekly dose of fun—and participants are invited to share scores and flag any genuine errors (with evidence) in the comments. A playful nod even directs quizzers to watch Gorillaz ft Sparks’ “The Happy Dictator” video.

articles.title: You be the judge: should my partner stop hankering after salt and pepper shakers?
articles.trailText: Debbie is happy to keep salt in a small bowl, but Gene wants smart shakers. You decide if their table needs a shake-up
articles.summary: Debbie enjoys using a Spanish ceramic bowl and wooden spoon for Himalayan salt, resisting Gene’s push for dedicated salt-and-pepper shakers, which he argues are more hygienic, convenient and elevate their table’s aesthetics. Debbie worries about clutter and sees shakers as pointless; Gene counters that sealed dispensers prevent finger-dipping, ensure portion control and improve presentation for guests. Guardian readers are split—some praise Gene’s attention to detail, others side with Debbie’s low-maintenance ethos—and an online poll invites further judgement.

articles.title: The peacock parent problem: how to survive being raised by a narcissist
articles.trailText: Psychotherapist Kathleen Saxton has written a book about growing up with a mother or father who is grandiose, entitled, exploitative and lacking in empathy. She discusses how to recognise the signs – and recover
articles.summary: Psychotherapist Kathleen Saxton’s new book My Parent the Peacock guides adult survivors of narcissistic parents through recognition and recovery. Drawing on her London and New York practice, Saxton outlines hallmark traits—grandiosity, exploitation, gaslighting and conditional love—and the lasting impacts into adulthood: anxiety, poor self-esteem and identity erosion. She differentiates narcissistic personality disorder from common selfishness, categorizes grandiose, covert and malignant types, and estimates up to 3% of UK adults have diagnosable NPD. Recovery centers on realisation, specialist therapy, firm boundaries (eg grey rock) or no contact, and rediscovering one’s authentic self.

articles.title: Hooray for Hollywood? Why tourists are giving the US a miss
articles.trailText: Visit California predicts 170,000 fewer visitors to the state this year – with Los Angeles and Yosemite national park hit hard. Will the Trump slump continue to deepen?
articles.summary: Visit California forecasts a 9% drop in international visitors in 2025—about 170,000 fewer—while Hollywood Boulevard traffic plunged 50% this summer. Contributing factors include January wildfires, negative Walk of Fame reviews and the Trump administration’s tough immigration policies and Canada tariffs, which have driven Canadian arrivals down 38%. Yosemite bookings halved over Memorial Day, Las Vegas visitation fell 8%, and Florida attendance slid from 19.4m to 15.9m. Overall US tourism is set to decline 8.2% with 25% fewer Canadians, a ‘wake-up call’ ahead of next year’s World Cup.

articles.title: What can Americans learn from the UK? How to cope with national sporting despair | Adrian Chiles
articles.trailText: America’s Ryder Cup defeat sparked some ugly behaviour among their fans. But, as some of us know all too well, losing can be a bonding experience, writes Adrian Chiles
articles.summary: For Americans, national sporting despair is rare, given dominance in their major team sports. Losing, writes Adrian Chiles, can be a powerful bonding experience: shared misery unites fans and deepens joy in victories. After the Ryder Cup defeat, some U.S. spectators showed ugly behavior and left early, lacking the humility and solidarity Europeans display when saluting opponents and commiserating together. In the UK, collective defeat during football finals or cricket Tests forges unity across regions and cultures. Chiles argues Americans miss this unifying ritual—"without despair there is no joy"—and could learn from British fans how to cope with and cherish sporting losses.

articles.title: A moment that changed me: I froze in a job interview – and it made me stop hiding my disability
articles.trailText: I had always been hyper-independent, preferring to get the wrong bus than ask for help with my visual impairment. When I finally acknowledged it, I was overwhelmed by the love and support of friends and strangers
articles.summary: At 16, after failing to read a screen during a fast-food interview, a partially sighted teen realised she’d been hiding her disability. Born with retinal dystrophy, she’d masked vision struggles at school and avoided help, even on buses and at restaurants. That rejection prompted acceptance: she began asking questions at appointments, requesting assistance from friends and strangers, and advocating for accessibility. Embracing support transformed her confidence, turning each barrier into a challenge and inspiring her to speak up for over 2 million people with sight loss in the UK.

articles.title: ‘Indolent and not photogenic’: can I make my reluctant cat a social media star in seven days?
articles.trailText: Olly isn’t an obvious influencer – but that could be said of many of the felines who rule online. Here is what happened when I set out to turn him into a sensation
articles.summary: Attempting to transform Olly—an indolent, unphotogenic black senior rescue—into a pet influencer in seven days, the author taps expert advice from Mark Wardle of Urban Paws and Instagram’s Lady Lola owner Niki. They test trends, carve a niche as a cat fitness guru, highlight Olly’s USPs, rebrand his account and prioritize simple, authentic clips. Despite modest gains (106 TikTok and 15 Instagram followers), they conclude that viral success demands consistent content creation, niche branding and resilience to online trolls—luxuries they lack—and leave Olly to his Amazon box.

articles.title: When shopping delivers a moral dilemma | Letters
articles.trailText: Letters: Readers respond to an article by Polly Hudson on whether they would keep goods delivered by accident
articles.summary: In response to Polly Hudson’s piece on accidental deliveries, two readers share dilemmas. Susan Wood recounts paying £255 for a British Heart Foundation coffee table sold on eBay only to discover another customer who paid for two tables took three, effectively stealing £255 from charity. The shop avoids police to protect donors; Wood urges publicising charity thefts. David Gomm describes receiving 36 kg of coffee instead of his usual 6 kg order, returning the surplus despite supplier indifference and fears his honesty might entangle an employee in a mistake investigation.

articles.title: My petty gripe: not only am I losing my livelihood to AI – now it’s stealing my em dashes too
articles.trailText: The humble em dash is being used as a tell that something is written by a large language model. But it’s James Shackell ’s favourite piece of punctuation, and he’s not ready to lose it
articles.summary: Freelance writer James Shackell recounts how his editor demanded he strip every em dash from his copy—once his favorite punctuation—because readers now associate those long pauses with AI-generated text. He explains em dashes mirror his jumpy thought process and were baked into algorithms when large language models trained on real writers. Shackell laments losing not just his income to automation but also a crucial stylistic tool, debating awkward alternatives like semicolons, run-ons or ellipses in defiant protest.

articles.title: ‘He loves splashing around’: UK pools host doggy dips for pets and owners
articles.trailText: Gourock outdoor pool in Inverclyde drops its humans-only policy on last day of the swim season – part of a trend at lidos around the country
articles.summary: Gourock outdoor saltwater pool in Inverclyde opens its final season day to dogs and owners in its annual Doggy Dip since 2019, letting pets like labs, poodles and Pekingese splash in heated, salt-buoyed water under lifeguard supervision. Owners seek saltwater buoyancy for fitness, fear therapy and joint-friendly exercise. The pool, featured on Blur’s album cover, adds sessions due to demand, rinses dogs post-swim and handles safety. Similar events run at Brighton’s Saltdean (Dogtember fundraiser) and Cheltenham lido, while private canine pools grow, led by Suffolk’s “senior splashmaker” Andy Brownlie establishing industry standards.

articles.title: My partner fantasises about men during sex – and it makes me feel undesired as a woman
articles.trailText: He swears it’s just a kink and he will never cheat, but I worry that one day he will leave me for a man
articles.summary: A woman’s partner relies on gay fantasies to be aroused, leaving her feeling undesired. Though he promised it’s just a kink and vows fidelity, she senses an imbalance: he never looks at her with desire and treats her more as a femdom. The original unspoken pact—sexual creativity in exchange for emotional security—once worked but now leaves her longing for genuine feminine desire. Psychotherapist Pamela Stephenson Connolly advises acknowledging and respecting her hurt, opening honest dialogue about mutual needs, and weighing whether the relationship’s support still outweighs her pain.

articles.title: ‘The vibes, the food, the people’: a night out in Burwood, Australia’s coolest neighbourhood
articles.trailText: Returning to the humble Sydney suburban centre of her teens, Rafqa Touma discovers busy streets, market stalls and photo booth karaoke
articles.summary: Rafqa Touma returns to her teenage Sydney suburb as Burwood, recently named Australia’s coolest and 16th globally, pulses with Korea Day festivities, bustling food stalls and live music. Over $100, she samples banh xeo tacos, Vietnamese pancakes, baklava and loaded chicken noodles from teenage magician vendor Dimi. As neon-lit Burwood Road thrives with Xi’an Eatery queues, lamb skewers and mochi gelato at Ice Kirin, she meets weekly regulars and locals. Her night ends with $5 photo‐booth karaoke. This vibrant blend of community, diverse cuisine and unexpected experiences cements Burwood’s soul.

articles.title: Branding of New Forest ponies is indefensible | Brief letters
articles.trailText: Brief letters: Wild pony treatment | Bring back prefabs | Cyclists and pedestrians | Fighting Reform | House of Guinness
articles.summary: In a brief letter, Jason Rose of Musselburgh decries the traditional roundup of New Forest wild ponies, criticizing foal branding and tail docking performed under the guise of preserving 'beauty and traditions'. He argues these invasive procedures inflict unnecessary pain, violate animal welfare, and exemplify outdated human customs unjustly overriding the ponies’ quality of life. He recalls reading the Guardian’s Country Diary praising the forest’s heritage but questions how such cruelty remains acceptable. Rose demands an end to these rites and recognition of the ponies as sentient animals deserving respect.

articles.title: Melissa Leong: ‘Life is not easy. Life is ugly and hard and unpredictable’
articles.trailText: Not wanting to ‘sugarcoat the less-than-ideal things’ in her life, the former MasterChef judge says the years she rose to fame were ‘a lot about survival and not much else’
articles.summary: In her memoir Guts, former MasterChef judge Melissa Leong lays bare a life shaped by depression, anxiety, bulimia, self-harm and sexual violence, chronic pain that derailed a music career, and the loneliness of reality TV. She recounts quitting a corporate job for a Tasmanian sheep dairy, navigating a hostile food-writing world, a public divorce, and backlash as the show’s first female judge. Embracing vulnerability and self-prioritization, Leong rejects societal norms, explores jiujitsu and UFC hosting, and insists life is ugly, unpredictable and a test of survival—her raw testament to resilience.

articles.title: The swag gap: can love survive when one partner is cooler than the other?
articles.trailText: Some people claim to have lost friends and lovers because they are so attractive and fabulous that everyone ends up envying them. But perhaps there is another reason they are driving people away ...
articles.summary: The article coins the term “swag gap” to describe relationships where one partner’s style, effort, or coolness vastly outshines the other’s, creating tension and imbalance. Using Justin and Hailey Bieber as a high-profile example—Hailey’s polished, fashionable presence dwarfed by Justin’s careless dress and posture—it characterizes the swag gap as a “giant red flag” that can erode confidence and attraction. Attempts to reconcile by either dialing down or artificially boosting one’s swag often feel awkward or insincere. Drawing parallels to Grease’s mismatched Danny and Sandy, the piece warns that without real alignment in effort and aesthetics, relationships risk collapse under the weight of their own swagger.

articles.title: The one change that worked: I gave away my last dress – and embraced the real me
articles.trailText: Growing up, I could never be the ‘girly’ girl others expected. Even after coming out as gay, I struggled to know what to wear. But I think I’ve finally found my look
articles.summary: When packing for a flat move, the author finally donated her sole black midi dress and embraced a trousers-only wardrobe she’d long favored. Raised neither conventionally girly nor bound by skirts despite school demands, she faced fresh pressures after coming out as gay—caught between ‘butch’ and ‘femme’ labels. Gradually experimenting with androgynous tailoring, she even wore a satin suit to a gala wedding and found that effort, not conformity, wins approval. Despite rising queer hostility, she feels most powerful in gender-nonconforming styles, reclaiming the fearless spirit of her childhood crow costume.

articles.title: Is it true that … women snore less than men?
articles.trailText: Women are less likely to report that they snore, but menopause, pregnancy and weight gain can all take their toll
articles.summary: Men are nearly twice as likely as women to snore, says UCLH ENT consultant Ryan Chin Taw Cheong, but the gap narrows after menopause (45–55) and in third-trimester pregnancy. Snoring arises from partial airway obstruction—soft palate, throat or epiglottis—when relaxed muscles collapse under gravity. Risk factors include alcohol, excess weight, allergies, nasal polyps, deviated septum or colds. Female hormones (oestrogen, progesterone) help tone airway muscles, but shifts in hormone levels and gestational weight gain increase women’s snoring. Women underreport their snoring due to stigma. New or worsening snoring can signal sleep apnoea; loud, disruptive snoring merits medical evaluation.

articles.title: A new start after 60: I rented out my flat and bought a bike. Now home is a tent and the open road
articles.trailText: Sarah Cook has pedalled more than 24,000 miles in the seven years since she left England for the US and beyond. She has no plans to stop
articles.summary: At age 60, former medical lab scientist and home-schooling mother Sarah Cook rented out her Cumbrian flat, bought a touring bike and four-season tent and set off alone along the Pacific west coast of the US. Completing a 111-day, Vancouver-to-La Paz ride, she discovered the freedom of nomadic cycling. Now 67, Cook has logged over 24,000 miles—from Europe’s Black Sea to Atlantic, California sequoias to Patagonia—living by two mantras (“It’ll work out” and “Just do the next thing”). Despite osteoarthritis, she camps in tents or sleeping bags between rentals, finding joy in daily pedal strokes and an ever-unfolding open road.

articles.title: ‘My past was chaos’: Iain Lee on abuse, cocaine, comedy, his on-air breakdown and his ‘sex addict’ father
articles.trailText: The broadcaster and comedian has been delighting and outraging audiences for almost 30 years. Off-air, his life has lurched from crisis to crisis. Has he finally found peace?
articles.summary: Broadcaster-comic Iain Lee, 52, recounts a career from pranks on Channel 4’s 11 O’Clock Show to a recent on-air breakdown, revealing sexual abuse at nine, cocaine, sex and alcohol addiction, ADHD and bipolar diagnoses, came out as bisexual in 2019, and five years’ sobriety. He’s retrained as a counsellor, digitised early TV archives and launches Impostor Syndrome, a solo show tackling lifelong self-doubt, built on saving suicidal callers live and aiding an accident victim. Off-stage, he proposed on Lake Como to producer Katherine Boyle, co-parents two teenage sons and is making peace with his “sex-addict” father’s legacy.

articles.title: The kindness of strangers: a Los Angeles bus driver got everyone onboard to sing me happy birthday
articles.trailText: The jolly driver had already done me a favour when I’d left my camera on board. Then he got on the microphone and said ‘Hey folks, it’s this guy’s birthday today’
articles.summary: While backpacking in 1980s Los Angeles on his 21st birthday, an Austrian traveler forgot his precious camera on a bus. After calling the transport authority from a nearby phone booth, he was surprised when the driver made a U-turn and returned it moments later. When the traveler mentioned it was his birthday, the friendly driver announced it over the PA, inviting around 50 passengers to sing “Happy Birthday.” The spontaneous celebration remains a cherished memory—only marred by the fact he didn’t capture a photo of the jovial driver.

articles.title: Why do people become leftwing or rightwing? Is it nature or nurture?
articles.trailText: The long-running series in which readers answer other readers’ questions. This week, a dive into the psychology of political attitudes. Are they moulded by our genes or by our environment and experience?
articles.summary: In this installment of the long-running ‘Question of the Week’ series, The Guardian examines the nature-versus-nurture debate in political ideology—leftwing or rightwing. Summarizing behavioural genetics and social psychology research, the piece highlights genetic heritability of ideological predispositions, parental and cultural influences on value formation, and life experiences that shape beliefs over time. Readers are encouraged to submit their own insights for inclusion in next week’s feature.

articles.title: Mary Portas looks back: ‘After Dad died, his wife made us homeless. I never got to be a teenager, instead I worked’
articles.trailText: The queen of shops on her tragic teenage years, her glittering rise through retail and her spiritual awakening
