articles.summary: Mary Portas, born in 1960, lost her mother at 16, became homeless when her father remarried, and assumed responsibility for her younger brother rather than experiencing a typical adolescence. Channeling hardship into drive, she rose through Harvey Nichols, founded Yellowdoor, fronted BBC Two’s Mary Queen of Shops, served as the UK retail tsar and now co-chairs the Better Business Act. After burnout, she embraced Vedanta philosophy and daily meditation, shaping a conscious approach to business. For Portas, true success lies in family moments and authentic human connections. Her memoir I Shop, Therefore I Am arrives 2 October.

articles.title: Dads need love, too: the men creating ‘a vulnerable space’ to be with their kids, and each other
articles.trailText: From a coffee club to a meditation group with self-affirmations, brothers are doing it for themselves
articles.summary: Ron Holden Jr. created Dads Coffee Club in Los Angeles—a bimonthly, agenda-free meet-up of 25–30 fathers and their kids at coffee shops and venues (recently the Broad Museum, with an upcoming outing to David Kordansky Gallery on Oct. 4)—to fill the gap left by “Mommy and me” programs. Similarly, Desmond Carter’s Mental Health Is Real Wealth and WalkGood LA’s YouGood? healing circles blend meditation, sound baths, journaling and affirmations. By offering diverse, stigma-free spaces, these initiatives help fathers—especially Black men—embrace vulnerability, self-care and mental health under societal pressures.

articles.title: Readers reply: What would happen if politicians actually answered the question?
articles.trailText: The long-running series in which readers answer other readers’ questions tackles what might occur if our elected representatives responded directly to questions put to them …
articles.summary: Readers in the long‐running Guardian series debate what would happen if politicians actually answered questions. Contributors say honesty would expose difficult trade‐offs—tax rises, migrant workforce reliance, industry donations—and could overwhelm the NHS, trigger public outrage or fainting spells. Some believe straight answers would boost voter trust and respect; others warn of dog’s abuse, shorter news cycles or selective fact‐checking. Suggestions include limiting responses to yes, no or don’t know. Overall, the thread reveals frustration with political spin, media complicity and a hunger for clear, accountable leadership.

articles.title: Dining across the divide: ‘There he was with his goatee, shaved head, tattoos – but never judge a book by its cover’
articles.trailText: A leftwing voting skeptic and tribal Tory party member struggle to agree on nationalism and the role of the state. Can they find any common ground over social media?
articles.summary: John, 64, Cirencester, ex-banknote manufacturer and tribal Conservative, and Jonny, 62, Oxford-based former mental-health nurse with left-wing/communist sympathies, meet at The 48 in Swindon. John admits misjudging Jonny’s tattooed, shaved-head appearance, but over Indian and Thai dishes (momo dumplings, goat curry, coconut rice) they bond. John defends national service and a collective “we,” decries politicians’ social-media pandering; Jonny champions localism, reluctant national identity, critiques broad democratic consent. They share boarding-school parallels and goat husbandry anecdotes, and despite ideological divides, plan to dine again after finding unexpected common ground.

articles.title: This is how we do it: ‘Over 30 years, our spark has dimmed in difficult times, but we’ve always got it back’
articles.trailText: After three children, Gavin and Lisa have sex less often these days, but it’s better quality and more meaningful than when they were younger
articles.summary: In 30 years together, Gavin and Lisa Price, both 48, have shifted from spontaneous university sex to scheduled, high-quality intimacy once or twice a month. Snoring and three children (6, 15, 17) mean they often plan time alone, sometimes improvised in showers or alternate rooms. Sex has become a meaningful ritual underpinned by decades of shared history, signals—eye contact, a dropped shoulder—and mutual trust. Both acknowledge body changes—Gavin’s bad back, Lisa’s menopause and post-pregnancy body image—and embrace confidence born of familiarity. Despite life’s challenges, they maintain a spark through laughter, music, and physical closeness, valuing intimacy’s evolution over novelty.

articles.title: ‘To them, ageing is a technical problem that can, and will, be fixed’: how the rich and powerful plan to live for ever
articles.trailText: When Xi Jinping and Vladimir Putin were caught on mic talking about living for ever, it seemed straight out of a sci-fi fantasy. But for some death is no longer considered an inevitability …
articles.summary: After Xi Jinping and Vladimir Putin speculated about using organ transplants to ‘live to 150’, tech reporter Aleks Krotoski exposes an accelerating immortality movement among Silicon Valley magnates, biohackers and aristocrats. She traces 2000s parabiosis studies by the Conboys, controversial ‘young blood’ clinics like Ambrosia, gene-tweaking nematode experiments and Bryan Johnson’s ‘Blueprint’ AI-driven anti-ageing regimen. These technofundamentalists envision literal fusion with AI, restructuring global governance and pursuing ‘longevity escape velocity’. Backed by Trump-era deregulation and elite political clout, they’re treating ageing as a purely solvable engineering problem, even as public health and eldercare face cuts.

articles.title: My cousin’s daughter didn’t invite me to her wedding and I feel deeply hurt | Ask Annalisa Barbieri
articles.trailText: You have done a lot for her over the years and understandably feel rejected, but this could be the start of a more adult relationship with her
articles.summary: A close, long-standing bond between you and your cousin’s daughter—from bridesmaid duties to a sponsored gap year—left you feeling rejected when she held an intimate wedding without you, only sharing photos afterward. You’re hurt after years of support, interpreting her omission as ingratitude. Annalisa Barbieri, citing psychotherapist Chris Mills, explains that differing values and life stages often lead to unintentional slights rather than deliberate exclusion. Your cousin’s daughter likely values you but chose a small celebration for budget or personal reasons. This could mark a shift toward a more equal, adult relationship, with future gatherings offering fresh opportunities to reconnect.

articles.title: The moment I knew: Adele was singing and tears rolled down my face. It felt as though the lyrics were about us
articles.trailText: At circus school, Chelsea Angell and Cal were ‘flirty friends’. During an emotional set at Glastonbury, she knew they belonged together
articles.summary: Performers Chelsea and Cal met aged 17 and 18 at Melbourne’s National Institute of Circus Arts in 2012, where buddy partnerships and shared muffins sparked a ‘flirty friends’ bond that blossomed into romance during a 2014 study trip to Paris. They briefly split when touring contracts took them to Germany and the UK, but reunited in 2016 at Glastonbury while Adele’s “Make You Feel My Love” confirmed their commitment. They toured separately, created a joint cabaret in 2017, weathered Covid in the Blue Mountains and have since built a shipping-container home in Queensland, now touring together year-round.

articles.title: I wanted to know if having a kid on a burning planet was right. I found that antinatalism is seriously taboo | Bri Lee
articles.trailText: Society has come a long way in making space for maternal ambivalence and the childfree movement, but those frameworks ask whether we want to have children, not whether we should
articles.summary: Bri Lee’s Seed uses its male protagonist to probe antinatalism amid climate crisis, uncovering a diverse, compassion-driven philosophy that prioritizes reducing human and environmental suffering. Despite scientific calls—like Ipsos citing fewer children as the top emissions curb—antinatalism clashes with religious norms, pro-growth economics and rising pronatalist agendas led by Trump, Musk and US policies favoring high-birth communities while cutting contraception. Lee spotlights hypocrisy: Australia’s government approving new coal mines for 1.7bn tonnes of CO₂ and young climate activists losing legal battles. She argues the taboo on asking ‘should we have children?’ stifles debate on population, justice and planetary survival.

articles.title: ‘Men seem to make life for women worse’: single US women share the woes of dating in 2025
articles.trailText: Here’s why some women feel like there’s little hope in the current dating pool of men – if they’re still in the market for one
articles.summary: According to Census and Morgan Stanley projections, by 2030 45% of US women aged 25–44 will be single—the highest ever. Hundreds of respondents cite desires for partners who are kind, emotionally intelligent, mentally and physically healthy, ambitious, financially stable, mature and committed to equal, monogamous relationships with shared values and family goals. They report men’s low effort, poor communication and social-media toxicity, plus educational and socioeconomic mismatches. While many feel lonely or biologically pressured, others embrace independence supported by financial self-sufficiency and career priorities.

articles.title: ‘Small wonders exist alongside our everyday lives’: Kisara Okada’s best phone picture
articles.trailText: Nature and manmade come together in the Tokyo-based photographer’s shot of a construction site
articles.summary: Kisara Okada, a Tokyo-based street photographer, shot with her phone the extended arm of a construction crane rising above redevelopment sites in Marunouchi, a former Meiji-era grassland modeled on London streets. Captured as benches lay empty under intense heat, a lone worker rounds off his shift beneath the crane. Embracing her theme of "sites of miracles the city has overlooked," Okada applied minimal editing to highlight layered intersections of nature and man-made structures, revealing the small, everyday wonders woven into Tokyo’s evolving urban fabric.

articles.title: Fun or frightful? Halloween Advent calendars hit the shelves
articles.trailText: Retailers stock up on countdown gifts as Britain’s enthusiasm for (and spending on) spooky holiday grows
articles.summary: Britain’s retailers are embracing Halloween Advent calendars, offering themed 13-to-31-night countdowns packed with horror dolls, KPop Demon Hunter keyrings and even The Nightmare Before Christmas trinkets. With Britons spending nearly £400 million on sweets annually, independent shops ordering calendars jumped 150% to over 2,000 outlets this year, and fancy-dress and decoration sales are up 70% year-on-year, outpacing the US. From Amazon’s selection to John Lewis’s £15 Squishmallows and The Box Party’s £25 “13 Nights of Halloween Spooky Spells” kits, demand is fuelled by consumers seeking communal, low-pressure seasonal treats—and better weather only sweetens the deal.

articles.title: The word sauna comes from which language? The Saturday quiz
articles.trailText: From Japanese spiders and Spanish pirates to Get Brexit Done, test your knowledge with the Saturday quiz
articles.summary: This Saturday quiz presents 15 quickfire trivia questions and answers spanning film, history, language and more: James Cromwell’s vegan turn in Babe; ancient Egypt’s three agricultural seasons; sauna’s Finnish origins; Taylor Swift and Travis Kelce’s engagement; the parliamentary filibuster named after a Spanish pirate; the Japanese spider as a crab; National Hunt bumper races; shared titles in Constable’s and Bosch’s Hay Wain; the Schmidt sting pain index; next four Olympic hosts; iconic sitcom duos; UK general-election manifestos 2017–2024; Hadrian’s Wall forts; symmetrical capital letters; and female African presidents.

articles.title: Why do we have hair and why are hospitals so clean? The kids’ quiz
articles.trailText: Five multiple-choice questions – set by children – to test your knowledge, and a chance to submit your own junior brainteasers for future quizzes ​
articles.summary: Molly Oldfield stages a five-question multiple-choice kids’ quiz probing everyday curiosities—from the evolutionary role of human hair in temperature regulation and UV protection to hospitals’ sterilization protocols and infection control. Each question, set by a child, challenges participants on medical hygiene, biological adaptations, and more. The feature doubles as a call for budding junior quizmasters to submit their own brainteasers. Fans of Oldfield’s ‘Everything Under the Sun’ podcast can also explore her companion titles, including the Quiz Book and the All Around the World edition.

articles.title: Blind date: ‘First impression? Warm, kind eyes and a great hug’
articles.trailText: Kammy, 27, an astrophysicist, meets Eliza, 30, a lawyer
articles.summary: Astrophysicist Kammy, 27, and lawyer Eliza, 30, met on a first blind date at You Call the Shots in London E9. They connected over astrophysics (Kammy’s PhD), Eliza’s switch from musical theatre to law, shared passions for language learning, travel (including Kammy’s Guatemala trip), reading and table-manners jokes. Kammy accidentally spilled wine; Eliza lauded his warmth and kind eyes. They stayed until closing, shared a quick station kiss, rated each other 9 and 8, and plan to meet again—at a pub quiz if not closer in location or on a Saturday.

articles.title: Tim Dowling: the time has come to enrol at dog school
articles.trailText: An incident at a farm shop suggests reform school is necessary – if our spoilt pooch can pass the interview process
articles.summary: Writer Tim Dowling describes taking his dog to a farm shop’s adjacent field, only for her to ditch the ball and dash into the shop, prompting a comic rescue run by his wife and other customers. Back home, they receive a dog school application; labeled “spoilt and badly behaved,” the pooch’s habits—pulling on the lead, jumping on visitors, refusing to return when called—are ticked off. Amid family banter, the dog performs tricks, while Dowling ruefully hopes she’ll make the interview stage.

articles.title: Craig Silvey: ‘Boys want to feel as though their experiences and inner world are validated and important’
articles.trailText: The acclaimed Jasper Jones author on raising three young daughters, identities forged in country life, and how literature can combat toxic masculinity
articles.summary: Craig Silvey, acclaimed author of Jasper Jones, reflects on life as a devoted father of three—toddler Matilda and newborn twins Hazel and Stella—while promoting his new middle-grade sequel, Runt and the Diabolical Dognapping. Based in Fremantle after a childhood on a Dwellingup apple orchard, he credits the work ethic of rural men and the influence of his grandmother and great-aunt for shaping his storytelling. Silvey argues fiction can challenge toxic masculinity by offering boys positive, empathetic role models and validating their inner worlds. Between baby wrangling and film development, he’s recalibrating the meaning of family and preparing future novels.

articles.title: Why everyone is lifting weights – and how to get started (whatever your size)
articles.trailText: Are reps or weights more important? Is it good if it hurts? How should I structure my workouts? Everything you need to know about resistance training, from the experts
articles.summary: Resistance training is rising in popularity due to proven health benefits—immune support, cognitive protection and longevity—and suits all ages and body types. Experts debunk myths about women getting bulky and kids’ or seniors’ strength training, recommending two to four weekly sessions with compound moves (squats, presses, deadlifts). Aim for 70–80% of your 1RM for 8–12 reps, using progressive overload and allowing recovery. Beginners can start on machines or free weights, with coach check-ins. Creatine offers modest performance gains. Structure workouts as full-body twice a week or split by muscle groups. Fuel workouts with balanced meals and 20–30g protein per post-session meal.

articles.title: Experience: I was almost killed when a pigeon made me crash my motorbike
articles.trailText: My face was so smashed up, you could fit a finger in the wounds
articles.summary: In Eastbourne last May, on her father’s 60th birthday, a 24-year-old rider with a newly earned motorbike license hit a parked Volvo after a pigeon smashed into her open helmet. Flung into the road, she suffered skull fractures, brain bleeds, shattered pelvis, broken ribs, shoulder, knee and finger, plus internal injuries. Her family—doctors and medics—stabilised her until paramedics arrived. After multiple surgeries and a month hospitalized, she spent three months bedridden and now copes with pelvic, facial nerve and brain damage. Grateful for her £1,000 helmet, she no longer rides on roads but tracks, and cherishes family time above all.

articles.title: I am 86 and on my own. How do I get to know my nice neighbour better? | Leading questions
articles.trailText: Trying to progress a relationship can feel awkward, writes advice columnist Eleanor Gordon-Smith . But it’s easier if you find something specific to do together
articles.summary: An 86-year-old widower feels lonely despite financial security and occasional family visits, following years of routine at home and the loss of social groups to Covid. He chats over the fence with a friendly neighbor and hesitates to ask her out for coffee for fear of awkwardness. Advice: suggest simple shared tasks or outings as though you’re already comfortable—tea, gardening, puzzles, local events or even sharing excess cake—to keep things informal, ease into deeper companionship and avoid a ‘big leap’ that might strain your budding friendship.

articles.title: Daylight saving haters rejoice: scientists confirm it’s bad for health
articles.trailText: US Congress is debating permanent daylight saving – but new research shows keeping clocks on standard time is least stressful on the body
articles.summary: Researchers at Stanford modeled how permanent standard time, permanent daylight saving and current clock changes affect circadian rhythms in every contiguous US county. Published in PNAS, their findings show year-round standard time minimizes circadian stress and could reduce obesity and stroke prevalence. Amid Congressional debate over the Sunshine Protection Act, the American Academy of Sleep Medicine, American Academy of Neurology and National Safety Council endorse permanent standard time to align social schedules with natural light, and national polls increasingly favor it over daylight saving.

articles.title: The experts: estate agents on how to find the perfect property
articles.trailText: Whether you are buying or renting, the UK property is a minefield. Here’s how to avoid the most common traps and get those keys in your pocket
articles.summary: UK buyers and renters should secure finances early—arrange mortgage-in-principle with an independent adviser and gather payslips, bank statements and deposits. Plan five years ahead with clear non-negotiables (parking, schools). Don’t rely solely on portals: register directly with local agents, follow them on social media and build rapport as a “top buyer/tenant.” Be flexible for viewings, carry a checklist (windows, radiators, boiler, noise), and always book a second visit with a builder or architect. Provide feedback, personalise offers with a heartfelt note, justify any lowball bid, accept chains, appoint a strong conveyancer and stay positive.

articles.title: Thursday news quiz: train names, banned games and a problematic moose
articles.trailText: Test yourself on topical news trivia, pop culture and general knowledge every Thursday. How will you fare?
articles.summary: Published every Thursday as the weekend approaches, The Guardian’s Thursday News Quiz No 216 tests your mettle against recent headlines, pop culture and general knowledge. This week’s questions cover topics from quirky train names to banned video games, a “problematic moose” story and tales of mischievous or kinky animals. There are no prizes, but participants are invited to compare scores and share results in the comments. Entrants spotting genuine errors—with clear evidence—can lodge complaints below. Alternatively, quiz takers are cheekily reminded they could be watching Poppy Jean Crawford’s Glamorous instead.

articles.title: You be the judge: should my daughter pay for the vase she broke in our holiday villa?
articles.trailText: Marlene believes Dani will learn a valuable life lesson by paying for her mistakes. Dani thinks the charge is ridiculous. You decide: who’s gone potty?
articles.summary: In a 10-day Malta Airbnb trip costing €1,100, host charged an extra £50 for a broken vase beyond the £100 cleaning fee. Marlene insists her 24-year-old daughter, Dani, pay for her accident to learn responsibility; Dani paid under family pressure but now plans to dispute via Airbnb, arguing the standard cleaning fee should cover such incidents. The dispute reveals tensions over respect, finances and adult accountability. Guardian readers are invited to weigh in on who’s in the right.

articles.title: Social media and weight loss drugs drive UK rise in facelifts in men and people in their 40s
articles.trailText: Number of procedures on men up by 26% as experts say cosmetic surgery has become normalised despite risks
articles.summary: UK facelift procedures rose 8% to 1,882 in 2024, with men’s cases up 26% (111→140). Social media pressure and weight-loss drugs (Ozempic, Wegovy), which can cause “Ozempic face,” have normalized facelifts for men and people in their 40s. The British Association of Aesthetic Plastic Surgeons warns of surgical risks (scarring, nerve damage, infection), weeks-long recovery and £15,000–£40,000 costs. Experts recommend psychological screening, choosing qualified surgeons and realistic expectations. Modern multifactorial techniques—fat transfer, endoscopic “scarless” lifts—offer natural, durable results.

articles.title: Fake Labubu dolls account for 90% of counterfeit toys seized at UK border
articles.trailText: Many of the 236,000 imitations of the fluffy figures found this year contain banned chemicals or pose choking risk
articles.summary: Pop Mart’s Labubu imitations made up 90% of the 259,000+ counterfeit toys (worth £3.5m) seized at UK borders this year. The IPO found 75% failed safety tests—containing banned chemicals or small detachable parts posing choking hazards—and 46% of buyers reported serious issues, from toxic smells to illness. The surge in fakes exploits Labubu’s viral popularity on social media and celebrity endorsements. A new IPO-led campaign with retailers, local authorities and influencers advises consumers to stick to trusted sellers, check UKCA/CE markings, review packaging quality and report suspicious toys to protect children from dangerous counterfeits.

articles.title: ‘People say I come across as incredibly boring!’ How to find love on the dating apps – whatever the obstacles
articles.trailText: Sick of swiping and messaging but never meeting anyone you like and who likes you back? Here’s what worked for some lucky couples
articles.summary: Chronic daters spend months swiping but often stall at messaging; US data show eight months and 3,960 profiles before a match, while Ofcom reports a 16% drop in top-app use. Meta’s AI assistant and 'surprise match' aim to combat swipe fatigue. Success stories: Liz (deleted Bumble after one date to focus singularly), Joseph (joined vegan Grazer to filter values), Hannah (tactical, honest photos to deter mismatches), Dan (personalized jokes and thoughtful gifts), Nicholas (proactive pandemic sign-up). Experts recommend mixing mainstream and niche apps, clear profiles, narrow pools, positive mindset, and serendipity.

articles.title: Moving to an island of 300 people, it took effort to become a local. But that hard work paid off
articles.trailText: I was looking for community when my husband and I relocated to Dangar Island. So I volunteered, invited people to dinner – and invited them again
articles.summary: After retiring, a migrant writer and her husband moved to Dangar Island, a 300-resident community on the Hawkesbury River outskirts of Sydney—seeking community. She volunteered as Hall Committee secretary, hosted dinners, joined the community-run café’s fundraising art show with her 'Flotsam and Jetsam' mosaic, then co-founded the island’s sculpture walk featuring 14 giant Scrabble tiles. Morning strolls among native birds, café chats, pantomimes, progressive dinners, yearly street parties and a children’s picture book share island life. Regular tea at the Riverboat Postman’s horn and jetty cocktails with neighbours cement her local status while preserving off-island friendships.

articles.title: A drunk driver hit our car, my three friends died, and I began a fight for my life – and my ballet career
articles.trailText: At 20, Marc Brew was the sole survivor of a terrible crash that killed his fellow dancers. Paralysed from the chest down, he had to learn to live in a new, uncharted reality
articles.summary: At 20, Australian ballet dancer Marc Brew was the sole survivor of a head-on crash with a drunk driver near Johannesburg that killed his three friends and left him paralysed from the chest down. After rehab in South Africa and Australia, he relearned to use his upper body but remained paralysed below the chest. Rediscovering dance in New York with Kitty Lunn, he developed a disability-driven style. His collaboration with Sidi Larbi Cherkaoui, An Accident/A Life, dramatises his ordeal. Based in Glasgow, Brew now leads his own company and performs internationally as a disabled artist and gay father.

articles.title: Tell us: have your views shifted to the right as you have aged?
articles.trailText: We would like to hear from people whose views have shifted right as they’ve aged, or if they’ve noticed it among older relatives
articles.summary: An open call for readers to share experiences of shifting right-wing views with age, or observing older relatives’ political drift. It asks how such changes compare across family generations, the impact on parent-child or grandparent-grandchild relationships, underlying reasons for ideological shifts, and strategies used to bridge political divides. The piece seeks personal anecdotes illustrating causes—from life events to societal influences—and reflections on efforts to foster understanding and maintain familial harmony amidst growing generational and ideological gaps.

articles.title: A moment that changed me: I told my dad I was queer – and he said he found it hard to love me
articles.trailText: The letter he slipped beneath my bedroom door was brutal. But our lost relationship became the furnace that forged me
articles.summary: At 15, the author told his father he was queer and found a brutal letter slipped under his door in response: “I found it hard to love you.” Cast out, he led a double life—suburban schooldays by day, London clubbing and party drugs by night—before discovering drag as his canvas. His creativity earned acclaim even as his dad struggled to accept him, finally cutting off contact after spotting him on a TV makeover show. That estrangement drove his career, turning paternal rejection into the “furnace that forged” his identity. When his father died without reconciliation, he embraced the peace of letting go.

articles.title: All suds, no substance: some laundry detergent sheets no better than water for stain removal, Choice study finds
articles.trailText: Omo continues to clean up at top of Choice rankings while Aldi products deliver mixed results – but experts say no detergent makes up for a bad washing machine
articles.summary: Consumer group Choice tested over 50 detergents—powders, liquids, capsules and sheets—on stains like makeup, mud, grass and blood. Omo dominated front loaders (powder 81%, Ultimate 3-in-1 capsules 77% and 76%) while capsules ranged widely (Active Expert 52%). In top loaders Aldi’s Trimat powder scored best at 66%. By contrast, laundry sheets fared little better—or worse—than water: Skipper 46%, Lucent Globe 45%, Restor 44% versus water 45%. Choice warns cost-per-wash varies and a better machine often beats pricier detergent.

articles.title: Shrinking shirts, tiny Speedos and ‘thigh guys’: why are men’s clothes suddenly so skimpy?
articles.trailText: First it was ankles. Then it was thighs. Now men are baring their navels in shirts never designed to be tucked in. What is behind this flesh-flaunting fashion moment?
articles.summary: Men’s tops have shrunk to waist-skimming tees and button-ups showcased at NYFW and sold by retailers, with DIY TikTok tutorials fueling the trend. Following 2023’s crop-top craze and this summer’s “thigh guy” wave, UK Speedo searches are up 41% and inseams dip as low as 3in. Inspired by Paul Mescal and a gym-centric “body as flex” culture, these styles bare navels and quads while balancing baggy trousers. Observers hail a broader queering of menswear and note reduced fabric use—though fast-fashion churn persists.

articles.title: I had sex with another man while my husband slept. Is he right to be furious?
articles.trailText: We recently began exploring group sex. But he insists I crossed a line one morning, and is punishing me with silence and distance
articles.summary: A wife in an open male-male marriage describes how a group sex session went awry when, after a consensual threesome and fivesome, she resumed sex with a guest while her husband slept instead of checking in. Her husband, who values honesty but often conceals his own sexting, feels she crossed an unspoken boundary and has withdrawn in silence. Psychotherapist Pamela Stephenson Connolly advises that open relationships demand explicit negotiation, especially for partners who struggle to express discomfort, and recommends pausing for clear consent before proceeding in new sexual scenarios.

articles.title: Houseplant clinic: what are the tiny mushrooms growing in the soil of my plant?
articles.trailText: These are the fruiting bodies of fungi that live in compost. They are toxic if eaten but not harmful to plants
articles.summary: These tiny mushrooms sprouting in your houseplant’s pot are fruiting bodies of compost-dwelling fungi, thriving in moist, organic-rich soil, especially after warm, humid periods. Harmless to plants but poisonous if ingested, they pose no direct threat—just pinch or cut them at soil level and discard to curb spore spread. To reduce recurrences, replace the topsoil or repot with fresh compost, let the top inch of soil dry between waterings, avoid waterlogged pots, aerate regularly, and position plants in bright, ventilated spots. Their presence signals healthy microbial activity. Keep pots away from children and pets.

articles.title: Stand up for the right of less able people to sit down | Letters
articles.trailText: Letters: Readers respond to letters about young people not giving up their seats to those who need them more
articles.summary: In a series of letters, readers describe instances of younger, able-bodied people failing to yield seats on London’s Tube and assistance at an airport to elderly or injured travellers. Holly Anderson recounts being offered a seat by one stranger while gym enthusiasts occupied priority seats beside her frail husband; Laurence Gibson details her four-week commute on crutches when only one pregnant woman sat for her; Peggy Sellers notes men ignoring elderly women at baggage claim. Writers call for greater awareness and active politeness towards those with greater need.

articles.title: Quadrobics: should you get on all fours and act like an animal to get fit?
articles.trailText: The latest workout craze is super-physical, ultra-exhausting and involves releasing your inner beast ...
articles.summary: Quadrobics, a new workout craze, has participants mimicking animal locomotion on all fours—walking, trotting and jumping—to challenge coordination, balance and strength. TikToker “Soleil” credits it with rapid weight loss and core definition, often donning a cat mask to evoke an “animalistic spirit.” Sports performance coach Jarrod Nobbe notes the constant engagement of abdominals, obliques and spinal stabilizers makes it a comprehensive, full-body routine. Quadrobics taps into primal movement trends, offering a playful, gym-free alternative suited to outdoor or home practice for those seeking functional, holistic fitness beyond traditional exercises.

articles.title: We all want big personal change at the push of a button – but here is how to actually achieve it
articles.trailText: Real growth develops from the inside out. The process involves giving up the illusion of control and discovering the liberation and limits of your own agency
articles.summary: NHS psychotherapist Moya Sarner argues that meaningful personal growth cannot be achieved at the push of a button; processes like potty training, therapy, relationships and learning need time, patience and acceptance of uncertainty. Drawing on her toddler’s potty training and her own psychoanalysis, she shows how applying pressure collapses progress. Instead, real change unfolds gradually, requiring tolerance of being a beginner, letting go of control, and embracing internal exploration. Therapist-patient work succeeds when pressure is held and examined, not relieved by instant fixes. Sarner finds this process grounding, more fulfilling and resistant to cancel culture and swipe culture. It offers realistic hope rooted in ordinary reality.

articles.title: The one change that worked: I used to sip Red Bull to get me out of bed – until I tried the 3-2-1 method
articles.trailText: It’s always been difficult for me to throw off the covers and get going. Now, a self-imposed short, sharp shock has brought order and urgency into my life
articles.summary: After years of relying on sips of Red Bull under the covers and failed wake-up tricks—from hiding her phone across the room to enlisting flatmates—a British writer with ADHD tried the 3-2-1 method. By counting down aloud “3, 2, 1” rapidly and leaping up on “one,” she now rises early, savours a slow coffee, completes morning tasks at a measured pace and reclaims her willpower. Although still not a natural morning person, she avoids last-minute scrambles, cultivates daily momentum and feels more in control of her life.

articles.title: Is it true that … doing puzzles prevents dementia?
articles.trailText: Completing a fiendish jigsaw certainly engages many areas of the brain, but genetics and other lifestyle factors also play their part
articles.summary: Roxi Carare, professor of neuroanatomy, clarifies that puzzles don’t prevent dementia but can delay symptom onset by stimulating blood flow and waste clearance in the brain. Engaging vision, memory, and association areas keeps vessel walls flexible, counteracting genetic risks, hypertension, diabetes, smoking, and poor diet. Additionally, the sense of achievement and social interaction from puzzles improves well-being and reduces loneliness—factors linked to age-related cognitive decline. Combined with regular exercise, a healthy diet, and group activities, puzzles help maintain brain function, though they can’t override genetic predisposition. Similar benefits arise from walking with friends, dance classes, and museum visits.

articles.title: ‘We’re exhausted – but not from doing too much’: can this woman help us survive the age of distraction?
articles.trailText: With three jobs, three children and a labradoodle, the behavioural scientist Zelana Montminy knows a lot about being pulled in all directions. What can her new book about finding focus teach the rest of us?
articles.summary: Behavioural scientist Zelana Montminy, juggling three jobs, three children and a dog, explores the crisis of distraction in her new book, Finding Focus. Arguing that attention, not time, is our scarcest resource, she warns that task-switching exhausts us and normalises burnout. Contrasting superficial productivity hacks, she champions focus as emotional resilience: choosing where to place clarity and presence. Montminy offers practical habits—time-blocking, mental dumps, micro-pauses, phone-free rituals and boredom tolerance—to reclaim attention, restore real rest and build lasting resilience, drawing on personal epiphanies and wildfire losses.

articles.title: The kindness of strangers: a man let me share his hotel room when I was locked out in Paris
articles.trailText: I was staying with a host family and they were asleep. The entrance code had changed and I was feeling stuck, hopeless – and quite hungry
articles.summary: After returning to Paris following a friend’s funeral, a student found himself locked out of his host family’s flat when the entry code changed unnoticed. Hungry and stranded late at night, he wandered with his suitcase, then received complimentary burgers from closing McDonald’s staff. While eating on a bench he met a fellow Brit—a bank executive—who offered him a place on his hotel room floor when he learnt of his plight. With his girlfriend’s blessing, he accepted and spent the night there, reminded of strangers’ generosity.

articles.title: What would happen if politicians actually answered the question?
articles.trailText: The long-running series in which readers answer other readers’ questions on subjects ranging from trivial flights of fancy to profound scientific and philosophical concepts
articles.summary: In this installment of The Guardian’s long-running reader-driven series, contributors are invited to ponder the consequences of politicians directly and honestly answering questions. The article poses the open-ended query “What would happen if politicians actually answered the question?” and calls on readers to share their insights or further questions via email. A curated selection of responses will appear in next Sunday’s edition, inviting political aficionados and curious minds to explore transparency, accountability and the mechanics of public discourse.

articles.title: Ralf Little and Will Mellor look back: ‘In our 20s, we acted like everything was a joke. Now there are fewer knob gags’
articles.trailText: The actors on forming a close bond on Two Pints, why it’s important to have rows, and how they feel about ageing
articles.summary: Ralf Little (b.1980) and Will Mellor (b.1976) reflect on their 20-year bond as co-stars on BBC’s Two Pints of Lager and a Packet of Crisps (2001–2011). They recall meeting at a Halloween party, live-audience filming with impromptu knob gags, and Friday-night antics. Now both enjoy acclaimed careers—Mellor in Line of Duty, Broadchurch and Mr Bates vs the Post Office; Little in Inside No.9, Doctor Who and podcasting—and embrace adulthood’s depth. They observe fewer childish jokes, a stronger friendship forged through rows, renewed creativity via their Will & Ralf Should Know Better podcast, and a nostalgic drive to keep exploring as they age.

articles.title: Readers reply: Can art save lives?
articles.trailText: The long-running series in which readers answer other readers’ questions on subjects ranging from trivial flights of fancy to profound scientific and philosophical concepts
articles.summary: Art on the Underground unveils Ahmet Öğüt’s 'Saved by the Whale’s Tail, Saved by Art' at Stratford, inspired by a Rotterdam accident where a whale tail sculpture halted an overrun train. Reader responses cite other life-saving roles: arts therapy for WWII schizophrenic patients like Allen Ginsberg; personal creative acts that staved off suicide; Magritte’s illusion; Olafur Eliasson’s climate installations; the unifying power of music and sporting events; a Trump-era boycott; and a Khmer Rouge guerrilla spared by a traditional dance performance. The piece concludes with international mental health helplines.

articles.title: Dining across the divide: ‘We disagreed on almost everything – it was great’
articles.trailText: A shift manager and an NGO worker clashed on everything from taxation to climate emissions. Would they part on bad terms?
articles.summary: At Sheffield’s Domo Restaurant, Richard, 52, a Gainsborough shift manager turned Reform voter, and Joe, 37, a Sheffield NGO worker and ex-Labour leftist, shared steak, prawns and olives over a night of spirited debate. Richard championed low taxes, trickle-down economics, empire ties and free movement with former colonies, arguing market-led growth will fund public services. Joe countered with calls for wealth taxes, state investment in green industries, robust welfare, refugee protection and urgent climate action. Despite clashing on taxation, migration and emissions, they found common ground, enjoyed the evening and vowed to meet again.

articles.title: For years I struggled with infertility and loss. Then I had a life-changing call with a psychic
articles.trailText: On some level, I realised it was a bit unhinged, writes the author and podcaster Elizabeth Day. But what did I have to lose?
articles.summary: Author and podcaster Elizabeth Day recounts 12 years of infertility, recurrent miscarriages and an egg-donor IVF cycle in Los Angeles that ended in another failed embryo transfer. Feeling unmoored, she books a phone reading with psychic “Alexia,” who reveals Day was a mother of six in a past life and urges her to release her lifelong desire for a child. The session gives Day unexpected relief, reframing her purpose toward writing her ninth book, hosting ‘How to Fail,’ and supporting others through loss. She emerges with lasting peace and renewed meaning beyond motherhood.

articles.title: This is how we do it: ‘Erotic photography unleashed my exhibitionist streak’
articles.trailText: When Dylan takes photos of Linda wearing sexy lingerie, it boosts her body confidence and her sex drive
articles.summary: Dylan, 57, and Linda, 67, discovered that private boudoir photography in lingerie sparked Linda’s body confidence and reignited their sex life. What began six months into their relationship as playful hotel snapshots evolved into regular at-home and holiday sessions: two-hour shoots experimenting with light and poses that culminate in intimate long nights. Linda, a breast cancer survivor, embraced her curves and NHS-reconstructed breasts on camera, boosting her exhibitionist streak and libido. Their mature, self-employed lifestyle now includes occasional lingerie splurges, photo sessions every few months and a thriving, immersive erotic ritual.

articles.title: Mouldy plates, burning pans, clouds of vape smoke: how to survive the horrors of the shared kitchen
articles.trailText: Whether it’s your first day at uni or your 10th year in a flatshare, there’s no telling what awaits you whenever you enter the communal kitchen. Here’s how to cook and eat with the minimum of squalor – and the maximum of safety
articles.summary: In the shared flat’s communal kitchen, common hazards include toxic byproducts on burnt non-stick pans (acrylamide, PFAS), bacterial pathogens from improperly cured or stored meat (campylobacter, salmonella, bacillus cereus), mould and fly-borne germs on neglected dishes, cross-contamination on unwashed surfaces and cloths, indoor vape-chemical exposure, and irritant chemicals in plug-in air fresheners. Experts recommend gentle soaking and wooden utensils for pans, separate boards and sealed containers for raw meat, frequent hot soapy wipe-downs of counters and cloths, proper ventilation instead of fragrances, and asking vapers to step outside.

articles.title: I moved abroad to live with my wife, but I’ve come to hate her country | Ask Annalisa Barbieri
articles.trailText: I’m not surprised you’re depressed, you put up with things that make you unhappy. But if you work out what you want, you can take steps to get there
articles.summary: After marrying 20 years ago and moving abroad to his wife’s country—sacrificing his preferred career and social circle—a man finds himself depressed and resentful of its culture, politics, and city life. Stuck by his son’s future university fees and his wife’s job, he feels trapped. Advice from Annalisa Barbieri and psychotherapist Mark Vahrmeyer urges him to identify and communicate his unmet needs, explore alternative education or financial options for his son, consider travel or eventual repatriation, and set clear five-year personal goals. Recommended resources include the podcasts “What It Means to Belong” and “Should we move?”.

articles.title: The moment I knew: 10 days after we met, I wrote him a marriage proposal
articles.trailText: When Daniel Clarke locked eyes with Nick Pelomis, there was an immediate spark. As their time together started to run out, he put pen to paper to express how he was feeling
articles.summary: In 2006 UK theatre producer Daniel Clarke met actor Nick Pelomis at the Adelaide Fringe Festival. Drawn to each other, Clarke pursued him via friends. During a walk through the Persian Garden, he fell in love and, ten days later, penned a marriage proposal which Pelomis accepted. Separated by continents, Nick won a Gay Times civil partnership contest and moved to the UK. They wed in a Thames-side ceremony with 30 guests, two cats and a chihuahua named Ziggy. Now approaching their 20th year together, they travel globally, support each other’s careers and credit their early leap of faith for lasting love.

articles.title: I had a stroke during an ocean swim. Most people passed by unaware. One didn’t
articles.trailText: When Graham Russell set out for a dip in powerful wintry surf, he had no idea the beach where he had helped save lives as a surf lifesaver would become the place where his own was changed
articles.summary: Graham Russell, a volunteer surf lifesaver and winter swimmer, suffered a stroke from a neck artery dissection during a challenging ocean swim at MacMasters Beach, NSW. Unaware by peers, he struggled ashore until a passing surfer flagged his distress, prompting surf lifesaver friends and paramedics to respond. Diagnosed with a cerebellar stroke, he made a near-full recovery on blood thinners and returned to the beach with medical guidance to avoid big surf, reflecting on dependence on community, faith, and the ocean’s restorative power. He now returns swim by swim, acknowledging his vulnerability and renewed gratitude for the lifesaving community and his ongoing bond with the sea.

articles.title: ‘Monochrome is a way of finding poetry in everyday life’: Mélissa David’s best phone picture
articles.trailText: Strangers passing by an image of a girl holding balloons gave the French photographer an opportunity to play with shadows
articles.summary: In front of Paris city hall under renovation, French photographer Mélissa David shot a spontaneous phone photo of a girl holding balloons framed by printed panels and passersby whose shadows created dynamic compositions. Forced to use her phone after forgetting charged batteries, David edited the image in Photoshop Express, converting it to monochrome to evoke poetry in everyday life. She regards editing as integral to her creative process and believes her work reveals her inner state while inviting viewers to project their own interpretations, transforming the image from a personal snapshot into a shared visual narrative.

articles.title: When did sabre-tooth cats diverge from domestic cats? The kids’ quiz
articles.trailText: Five multiple-choice questions – set by children – to test your knowledge, and a chance to submit your own junior brainteasers for future quizzes ​
articles.summary: An interactive quiz for children featuring five multiple-choice questions chosen by young readers—including one on the timing of the sabre-tooth and domestic cat evolutionary split—designed to test knowledge across science, history and geography. Hosted by Molly Oldfield’s Everything Under the Sun platform (podcast and book series), this edition prompts kids to explore diverse topics from prehistoric evolution to world cultures and invites participants to submit original junior brainteasers for future quizzes, fostering curiosity and community involvement. Published by The Guardian’s Life & Style section, the child-authored format emphasizes peer-driven learning and encourages families to share and discuss answers together at home or in the classroom.

articles.title: In 2009, who crashed his Cadillac Escalade into a fire hydrant? The Saturday quiz
articles.trailText: From Doublethink, memory hole and Newspeak to American Flyers and The Flying Scotsman, test your knowledge with the Saturday quiz
articles.summary: A 15-question Saturday quiz tests general knowledge: UK’s largest river by discharge (River Tay); the hit albums The Wall vs Off the Wall; quiz host Victoria Coren Mitchell’s $2.5m poker wins; the Saola’s 2013 sighting; Rome’s Victor Emmanuel II Monument; Tiger Woods’s 2009 Cadillac Escalade fire hydrant crash; the Chancellors of Oxford and Cambridge; the Tarte Tatin pastry; literal meanings behind Bible, Qur’an, Torah; cycling films Breaking Away, American Flyers, The Flying Scotsman; Julius Caesar’s wives; Inigo Jones’ Banqueting House, Queen’s House, Covent Garden; Orwellian terms from Nineteen Eighty-Four; noble gases’ neon-light colors; and famous overtures by Beethoven, Berlioz, Tchaikovsky, Brahms, Dvořák and Elgar.

articles.title: Blind date: ‘The restaurant staff reacted with glee when we told them we were going on somewhere’
articles.trailText: Niamh, 27, who works in classical music, meets Harry, 30, a public sector consultant
articles.summary: Niamh, 27, a classical musician, and Harry, 30, a public-sector consultant, met at Bubala in London N1 on a blind date. Seeking a witty, well-dressed Irish partner, Niamh was struck by Harry’s tattoos and style; he admired her leopard-print top and creative streak. They bonded over shared London roots, a mutual driving instructor, tattoos’ stories, theatre, trainspotting and Baltic countries. An awkward staff cheer when they planned to move on led to a hasty curtain escape. They continued in a Scottish pub, kissed, scored each other 8–8.5/10 and exchanged numbers, anticipating friendship.

articles.title: Tim Dowling: we’re low on milk … the kids must have moved back home
articles.trailText: Having flown the nest, two of our sons are now back under our roof – and the third lives just around the corner
articles.summary: Freelance writer Tim Dowling describes how an ordinary Saturday morning is upended when his two eldest sons return home—one arrives with half his former belongings, the other joins him at the kitchen table engrossed in an online puzzle. Their mother imposes new supper alerts via calendar notifications, leaving Dowling fumbling tech and grocery logistics: need for big milk and beer mounts. Amid flat-hunting negotiations, storage reshuffling under the stairs, and app miscommunication, the eldest son ultimately orchestrates an ambitious stir-fry for five. Domestic routines flex to multigenerational living dynamics.

articles.title: Learning to live with the loss of a friend | Letters
articles.trailText: Letters: Readers respond to an article by Justin Myers and share their own experiences of grief
articles.summary: Letters in response to Justin Myers’ essay on losing a best friend describe readers’ experiences with non-familial grief: an academic mourning an Irish-American folk singer student who died during COVID; a woman coping with her “soul sister’s” death whose grief is often invalidated; a correspondent silenced by disbelief after a friend’s suicide; a widow who lost her longtime friend; and a roundup of international helplines. Contributors argue that societal support and vocabulary for friendship loss lag behind familial bereavement norms.

articles.title: Dining across the blind date divide | Brief letters
articles.trailText: Brief letters: A crossover column | Wedding faux pas | Punishing wrongdoing | Profound poetry
articles.summary: Letters respond to recent Guardian features: Nick Odell (Huddersfield) suggests a crossover column, “Dining Across the Blind Date Divide,” blending the TV shows Dining Across the Divide and Blind Date with starters, wine lists and political sparring. Valerie Gidlow (Faversham) recalls her husband’s wedding faux pas as an usher at the wrong church. Peter Wilson (Windermere) decries Britain’s need for specific laws to compel public bodies to tell the truth. Roland White (Bognor) shares shedding tears over Carol Ann Duffy’s poem and laments today’s obscene world. Readers are invited to submit letters.

articles.title: Miranda Tapsell: ‘I put pressure on myself: will this help or hinder my mob?’
articles.trailText: Just weeks after giving birth to her second child, the actor and writer discusses Darwin, her first love and her commitment to creating complicated Indigenous characters
articles.summary: Weeks after her second child’s birth, actor-writer Miranda Tapsell is promoting Top End Bub, the Amazon Prime spin-off she co-wrote and stars in, which follows guardianship, family duty and ambition set in Darwin. A NIDA alumna whose career began in Belvoir’s Yibiyung, Tapsell broke out in Mabo, The Sapphires and Love Child before co-writing the hit Top End Wedding. She balances joy with political intent and pressures of Indigenous representation—"will this help or hinder my mob?"—while expanding her agency as writer-producer. She’s developing a Jorjia Gillis dark comedy at Griffin Theatre and co-hosts ABC’s A Portrait Artist of the Year.

articles.title: More kissing, less kimchi: seven surprising ways to boost your gut health
articles.trailText: From gardening and humming to getting a dog – there’s more to boosting your gut microbiome than Greek yogurt
articles.summary: This article outlines seven non-dietary strategies to enrich your gut microbiome: exchanging oral microbes via kissing (choose healthy partners), exposing yourself to soil by gardening or going barefoot in nature, cooking then cooling starchy carbs to form resistant starch, practicing deep nasal breathing to activate rest-and-digest mode, eating at least 75% dark chocolate for polyphenols, stimulating the vagus nerve through gargling or humming, and owning pets (especially dogs) to diversify household microbes.

articles.title: Five o’clock dinner crowd: why are young Americans eating so early?
articles.trailText: Gen Z and millennials’ dinner reservations are reportedly inching earlier as they take advantage of happy hour deals
articles.summary: Gen Z and millennials in the US are booking dinner reservations earlier—around 5pm—to capitalize on happy hour deals, align meals with circadian rhythms and fit work-from-home schedules. OpenTable data shows 5pm bookings rose 11% year-over-year (20% in New York), 6pm up 8% and 8pm up 4%. TikTok users like Samantha Stobo champion “dinner by 6, in bed by 9,” and 73% of Gen Z hold gym memberships, underscoring wellness priorities. Restaurateurs report an influx of early diners and are trialing reverse happy hours. Mutable dinner norms reflect evolving economic and health trends.

articles.title: Create your own beer garden – hops are easy to grow and will keep you in tasty ale
articles.trailText: To make home-brewed beer, why not grow your own hops? They’re easy to propagate from a rhizome or stem cutting, though they need plenty of room
articles.summary: This guide shows how to grow hops for home-brewed beer, from planting rhizome or stem cuttings in spring to harvesting papery cones filled with lupulin in late summer. Plants need full sun, fertile, well-drained soil, sturdy trellis support and ample space. Wear protective gloves to avoid hooked hairs. Only female plants yield cones; harvest when they turn green-yellow and fragrant. After picking, dry fully or freeze before brewing. Hops can also be steeped as a bitter, sleep-inducing tea.

articles.title: Experience: I lived underwater for 100 days
articles.trailText: I put myself forward as a human guinea pig to study the effects of long-term sub-aquatic living. Not everyone can say they have befriended a lobster and a shark
articles.summary: Biomedical researcher and ex-naval diver spent 100 days in Jules’ Undersea Lodge, 30 ft below a Key Largo lagoon, at 1.7 atm for Project Neptune 100. His routine: 5 am push-ups, resistance workouts, coffee, self-administered heart/brain/blood/urine/saliva tests, 9 pm meditation and eight hours of vivid REM sleep. He took vitamin D, had weekly psychology sessions, and taught via Zoom. He observed a lobster moulting and befriended a nurse shark. Findings: ¾ in spinal compression reversed post-mission, collagen and stem cell production rose, REM doubled, he lost 23 lb and 100 cholesterol points. He cracked a tooth on day 12; data support future Mars habitat studies.

articles.title: My boyfriend sees sex as a competition he is losing. How can I change his mind?
articles.trailText: Masculine adequacy is a curse, writes advice columnist Eleanor Gordon-Smith . Beyond assuring him he meets the standard, could you help him to see the standard doesn’t matter?
articles.summary: A reader’s boyfriend treats sex like a contest—worried his performance and size fall short—likely fueled by absent-father insecurity and cultural myths of masculine adequacy. Eleanor Gordon-Smith suggests that simple reassurance he meets male standards won’t free him from them. Instead, she advises shifting the focus: explore what his partner genuinely likes, use candid, detailed communication, co-create novel experiences, and deprioritize abstract ideals from porn and pop culture. She also recommends therapy or self-help resources to dismantle competitive thinking, helping him see sex as mutual discovery rather than a performance.

articles.title: How I learned to stop worrying and love the snakes in my ceiling
articles.trailText: Overcoming my terror of new housemates was gradual but by observing them I learned that pythons can be beautiful and clever
articles.summary: Living in a 1920s Queenslander in Brisbane, the author overcomes a long-held terror of snakes after discovering eastern carpet pythons nesting in her ceiling. By naming the first visitor Sylvia and observing her graceful jaw movements, tongue flicks and shedding cycle, she comes to admire their beauty and intelligence. Subsequent pythons—including the aggressive “Shitty” and the juvenile “Slinky”—reinforce lessons of individual personality, wild-animal respect and ecological benefits such as rodent control.

articles.title: How will childhood be changed by AI toys? | Letter
articles.trailText: Letter: Our study is looking into how toys powered by AI can affect children’s development and their right to privacy, write Dr Emily J Goodacre and Prof Jenny Gibson
articles.summary: Dr Emily J Goodacre and Prof Jenny Gibson at Cambridge’s Play in Education, Development and Learning centre are researching how AI-powered toys shape early childhood development, social bonding, safeguarding and the child’s right to privacy. They probe how toys respond to children, affirm emotions, share conversations with parents or third parties, and convey social cues. They warn £74 AI companions may widen the digital divide—privileged kids gain supervised AI exposure and literacy while low-income families face unregulated risks—and urge public dialogue to inform parents and policymakers.

articles.title: Thursday news quiz: stranded punters, ice-cream quitters and a very naughty choir
articles.trailText: Test yourself on topical news trivia, pop culture and general knowledge every Thursday. How will you fare?
articles.summary: The Guardian’s weekly Thursday News Quiz No. 215 has been restored after its summer hiatus, inviting readers to test themselves on current affairs, pop-culture and general-knowledge trivia—highlighting stranded punters, ice-cream quitters and a very naughty choir in a sillier pub-quiz format. There are no prizes; it’s purely for fun. Participants can post scores, highlight any egregious errors (with proof) in the comments and enjoy a bonus recommendation: watch Sparks’ video “Porcupine,” starring Self Esteem.

articles.title: You be the judge: should my housemate stop brushing her teeth at the kitchen sink?
articles.trailText: Raquel doesn’t believe ADHD excuses Gina’s bad habits. You decide who needs to brush up on their etiquette
articles.summary: Roommates Raquel and Gina clash over Gina’s habit of brushing her teeth in the kitchen sink and drinking straight from the bathroom tap. Raquel, disgusted by toothpaste foam in her cooking space and direct tap contact, insists Gina confine oral care to the bathroom sink and use a cup. Gina, who has ADHD, argues that multitasking routines, sink rinsing and shared plumbing make it harmless, and that Raquel’s demands unfairly single her out. Guardian readers largely side with Raquel on hygiene and shared-space etiquette, urging Gina to accommodate her flatmate’s comfort. An online poll invites readers to decide if Gina must clean up her act.

articles.title: Oodles of Lucys: survey reveals Australia’s most popular dog breeds and names
articles.trailText: Australians leave the television or radio on for pets, take time off work to care for them and bring them on holidays, report finds
articles.summary: A recent Animal Medicines Australia survey finds 73% of households own pets, with dogs in 49% and cats in 34%. Owners treat pets as family—buy presents, cook meals, leave on TV/radio, even take them on holidays—driving $21.3 bn in annual spending, half on food. Human names like Harry, Lucy and Daisy top lists; food monikers (Taco, Oreo) rise. Labradors, goldens, German shepherds and border collies lead purebreds, while groodles (poodle–golden crosses) spearhead designer breeds. Yet 33% of dog owners skip daily walks and rising vet costs force some to delay care. Based on 2,450 respondents, results were weighted to census data.

articles.title: ‘It was a bad dream – but I never woke up’: what it is like to lose your best friend
articles.trailText: For 25 years, Justin and Nichola were an essential part of each other’s lives. Then, one random Wednesday, came a terrible, wrenching phone call
articles.summary: Justin Myers recalls a 25-year friendship with Nichola, born of shared student poverty and forged through life’s milestones—coming out, babies, careers and Sunday roasts. Their bond ended abruptly when Nichola died unexpectedly one random Wednesday. Justin and their mutual friend Emma navigated funeral tributes, administrative hurdles and a canceled holiday while confronting raw grief and the guilt of ‘justifying’ friendship loss. He describes the hollow routines that follow—a missing voice in daily life—and argues that society undervalues bereavement between friends. Now he honors Nichola by living fully, preserving her legacy for her sons.
